item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded: We are looking for bloggers. PCMRHub is an open non-profit community. Every penny we make from donations and ads goes towards giveaways. If you would like to try blogging on our site let an admin know and we can hook you up.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: PCMRHub. The best PC Hardware and Gaming community on Facebook. Giveaways, Hardware and Gaming articles, Cool Merch!!!!!

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

Name:Randy

Subject:Concerning pcmrhub.com
Message:Hi, My name is Randy and I was looking at a few different sites online and came across your site pcmrhub.com. I must say - your website is very impressive. I found your website on the first page of the Search Engine. Have you noticed that 70 percent of visitors who leave your website will never return? In most cases, this means that 95 percent to 98 percent of your marketing efforts are going to waste, not to mention that you are losing more money in customer acquisition costs than you need to. As a business person, the time and money you put into your marketing efforts is extremely valuable. So why let it go to waste? Our users have seen staggering improvements in conversions with insane growths of 150 percent going upwards of 785 percent. Are you ready to unlock the highest conversion revenue from each of your website visitors? TalkWithLead is a widget which captures a website visitors Name, Email address and Phone Number and then calls you immediately, so that you can talk to the Lead exactly when they are live on your website while they're hot! Try the TalkWithLead Live Demo now to see exactly how it works. Visit: https://www.talkwithlead.com/Contents/LiveDemo.aspx When targeting leads, speed is essential - there is a 100x decrease in Leads when a Lead is contacted within 30 minutes vs being contacted within 5 minutes. If you would like to talk to me about this service, please give me a call. We do offer a 30 days free trial. Thanks and Best Regards, Randy

item.title: Brand New Hardware for Cheap! (PCPartPicker)
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded: Friday March 3rd, 2017 | Adib Chowdhury Amazon is, without a doubt, the most popular online retailer in all aspects. The site is viewed as a great place for PC gamers to purchase their hardware at lower prices than physical stores. Low prices can certainly be found on Amazon, but there is a website that's proven to be a haven of a sort for purchasing PC hardware, which should be widely known to anyone remotely interested in building their own computers for ease of use, cheaper prices, automatic compatibility checks, and more! PCPartPicker.com is the most convenient website for any person planning to build their own computers. It provides a streamlined platform that automatically detects incompatibilities between hardware, chooses the cheapest retailers for each part, and allows the customer to order all their parts from different retailers at once. At the time of writing, the i7 7700k would cost $475 CAD on Amazon, but PCPartPicker automatically chooses the retailer with the cheapest price for the product, which is $458 CAD from vuugo. After compiling all the parts for the computer, the savings could turn over 8 more gigs of RAM, or even a higher tier graphics card! PCPartPicker is the most streamlined platform for consumers purchasing hardware. It automatically provides the cheapest prices per part, calculates wattage and compatibility, and allows the consumer to purchase all their parts quickly and easily. Using PCPartPicker makes the computer buying process almost as easy as gaming on a PC. Note: In order to find the version of PCPartPicker with your currency, select your country in the top right corner.

item.title: 8 EASY Ways to Save Money on Your Gaming PC
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded:
Saturday March 4th, 2017 | Adib Chowdhury
  1. Identifying Your Needs
Everyone wants the GTX 1080 Ti, 1070, Titan, or any other high end video card, but the simple fact is that buying these graphics cards are often a waste of money. Its very simple to build a computer that outperforms consoles at similar prices, but assuming that the highest end graphics cards are required will make it very difficult to buy the best card for the price. If the only games you wish to play are League of Legends, CS: GO, and other lightweight games, a graphics card under the price of $100 will suffice, such as the GTX 750 Ti/GTX 1050/RX 460. These cards are priced very competitively, and can play these titles with ease. Even AAA titles will be able to run at respectable settings with these graphics cards. Choosing the best graphics card that suits the games you play will save your wallet hundreds of dollars in the long run. Its simply unreasonable for someone who wants to play LoL to spend $650 on a GTX 1080. 2. Upgrade Your Current PC Most people have PCs in their homes for work, school, or entertainment. These computers are often fairly powerful, with i5s and i3s, which are generally the CPUs of choice for any gaming PC. In many cases, a work PC can be transformed into a full-fledged gaming PC by simply adding a graphics card. The computers power supply must be brought into consideration, but there are graphics cards specifically designed to be added to normal computers, such as the GTX 750 Ti/1050/1050 Ti/RX 460. If the PC is remotely recent, there is a high chance it will have the necessary PCI slot. These graphics cards require very little power, and produce impressive performance for their prices. Of course, some people will want to install stronger graphics cards that require more power. If the case in question is sized normally, there is a good chance that the power supply can also be upgraded. There are many tutorials online to learn these skills. 3. Combo Deals When browsing for parts on sites such as Newegg, it is very likely that you will come across a combo deal. When buying multiple parts together, such as a CPU, motherboard, and RAM, companies often reward you with a discount, which can range from $10, and even as high as $50 depending on the products. 4. Reusing Old Parts This tip goes hand in hand with #2. In some cases, your computer will be unusable. The processor may be too old or slow to be able to handle any games. The motherboard may be too old for a modern graphics card. In this case, building from scratch is often necessary. However, there are many parts that are almost always salvageable, such as the hard drive and RAM. Reusing these components in your new build could potentially create up to $100 in savings. 5. Buying Components with Games The RX 480 released with Battlefield 1 for a short time, which is a very popular game. This could save the customer $60 if they were to purchase the game. Even if the game is uninteresting, it can be sold on websites such as G2A for profit, which is better than a mail-in-rebate. 6. Subscribing to Retailers Nobody wants to be spammed into oblivion from different retailers with their deals. However, subscribing to sellers by email can be extremely helpful when searching for good sales. On Newegg, they release Flash Sales that can last for under a day, and the deals are often amazing! If youre not interested in having your inbox filled with these emails, a second email can be created just for finding deals. PCPartpicker is a great site to compare prices between websites. 7. Buying Older Generation Components Everyone wants to own the i7 7700k, or the GTX 1080. Every year, theres a new generation of components, which offer very little increases in performance for the price hike. Paying for the i5 7600K for $200 seems almost useless when an i5 2500k can be purchased for $50, and can be compared to the newer i5s when overclocked. 8. Buying Parts Used Your buck will only be banged to its full potential if parts are purchased used. Its very likely that PC gamers purchase parts used more often than brand new. Many of the fears behind buying used parts are often unnecessary. Up to 50% can be saved when buying parts used.

item.title: 10 PC Gore Pics That Will Make You CRINGE
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded: When you're building a computer, mistakes happen, sometimes you break a piece of hardware. But not as bad as these guys. Check out these ten pics of hardcore PC gore! 10. Have you ever watched as several hundred dollars just burned away in front of you? The owner of this Quadro has. 9. Modern Intel chips don't have pins, but for some reason AMD refuses to switch to contacts on the bottom of their processors, leading to broken CPUs and PCs. 8. Have you ever had a CPU cooler that was a bit too big for your case? Normally you'd just get a new cooler. Not this guy. 7. When you're traveling, how you transport your GPU can be a problem. They're fragile and expensive, so you probably want to keep an eye on it. But use some common sense when to decide where to put it. 6. Someone let this Motherboard sit around without cleaning it off for so long that it now looks like an ancient city that's been sitting dormant for hundreds of years. 5. Losing your CPU cooler mounting hardware can be frustrating, but getting "inventive" and using zip ties isn't a good idea. It looks bad, and it's not going to hold the cooler on well enough. 4. Occasionally, the inverse of the problem AMD's chips have happens and an Intel Motherboard gets it's pins bent. 3. It's kind of a meme at this point, but sometimes new PC builders do put CPU thermal paste on the underside of the chip. 2. I know you get that feeling when you're putting the power adapter into your GPU that you're going to break it, that you're using too much force. I've always told people that you'll probably feel like you're using too much force. This guy actually was. 1. I don't know how someone could mess up this badly, but I doubt Recuva is going to be able to get the data off this drive. Jimmy Nichols - 3/4/2017

item.title: Vulkan Receives HUGE Update at GDC!
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded: On March 2nd at GDC, Khronos announced that Vulkan API 1.0.42 has Explicit Multi-GPU support, among other improvements. Now you may be asking, "What exactly does that mean?" Essentially, this enables the Vulkan API to see and use multiple GPUs as one unit (with a single shared memory pool, thanks to the sharing extension set in the update). This is a huge improvement, as this enables games to utilize AFR and SFR. But that's been done with older APIs. What's really exciting though, is that this makes VR SLI possible under Vulkan, which assigns GPUs to a separate eye in VR games, greatly improving performance, and hasn't been widely implemented. It will take time for developers to implement multi-GPU support in their games, and the new multi-GPU extensions are still experimental at the time with full implementation into Vulcan planned for the future, reported by TheTechAlter. Likely, we won't see any Vulkan games with multi-GPU support for a while. You can check out Khronos' full GDC press release here. Jimmy Nichols - 3/4/2017

item.title: Expensive Pixels - A Brief History of CS:GO and it's Weapon Skins
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded: "Hey bro, you NEED this $400 HDMI cable for PC gaming! It delivers the best, most high-quality pixels to your monitor. And don't forget the protection plan!" That's probably what comes to mind when you think "expensive pixels." The pushy electronics salesman on commission shoving overpriced cords in your face. But can you believe that people pay more for cosmetic items than those cables? On August 21st, 2012 Counter Strike: Global Offensive released, with a very different landscape than the current game. Originally, ingame cosmetic items that replace the normal weapons, interchangeable knives, and gloves, called skins, weren't even there. It wasn't until August 13th, 2014, almost two years later, that The Arms Deal update added weapons skins, as well as the silenced M4A1-S and USPS to the game. CS:GO was already seeing an increase in players, but after the update the userbase exploded. Now, likely the game would've seen a continued uptrend without the addition of skins, but no one can argue their role. Initially there were over 100 weapon skins added, with more added regularly and a system implemented later that enabled the community to submit weapon skins to be sold and receive a portion of the money made from them, as well as interchangeable decorated knives and recently, on November 8th, 2016, interchangeable decorated gloves. These items are received by either getting a random item from certain sets of skins at the end of a match, or from unlocking a case that you received in the same way you receive dropped weapons, with a key that costs $2.50. After getting an item, users can trade them with other users and sell them on what is known as the community market, where the value is assigned by how much other users are willing to pay for it, in money only usable on Valve's Steam service to buy other ingame items, virtual trading cards, or video games. After a while people began exchanging these ingame items for real-world money, either directly or through third party services for as little as a cent, with some of the most expensive regularly traded items trading for 1225 ingame keys, or over $3000 at their highest with others being even higher. But it wasn't long before something Valve never saw coming happened: sites where users could gamble using the ingame items started popping up. These sites allowed users to place bets on professional Counter Strike matches, as well as play virtual versions of casino games. The sites soon came under heavy criticism by many, as they didn't do much, if anything, to verify users' ages before they were able to gamble on the site. People even claimed that some sites were trying to appeal to children specifically with advertising campaigns involving YouTube personalities. Valve didn't take action against CS:GO gambling websites until July 19th, 2016, as reported by TechRaptor, when they sent a Cease and Desist order to 23 gambling websites following a boom in controversy; part of which was what came to be known as the TmarTn scandal, where it was revealed that two YouTube personalities, TmarTn (Trevor Martin) and ProSyndicate (Tom Cassell), owned and operated a gambling site that they also advertised without disclosing that they owned, as reported by H3H3 in his video titled "Deception, Lies, and CSGO" The number of people playing CS:GO, as well as the prices of many of the ingame items, had been on the decline for a few months before these events unfolded, and they didn't do anything to improve them. After these gambling sites closed, CS:GO saw the biggest dip in playership it had had in a while, with only around 630,000 people playing the game the week before the ESL One 2016 Major, a Valve sponsored competition with a large prize pool and a lot of promotion by Valve. At the time, roughly 830,000 to 850,000 people had been playing the game in the week before a Major. Many of these gambling sites still exist today, however, with the largest and most prolific among them shut down, or only serving people outside the US, a big blow has been dealt. Gambling sites had, and still have to a large degree, been taken out of the public eye. But since the initial controversy fizzled out, Valve hasn't taken action against any other gambling sites. We may see, in the near future, more gambling sites take up the role as the juggernauts of the industry, and with it, become targets of further controversy. In the months since, the market for CS:GO skins has made a comeback that many doubted would happen. The AK-47 | Redline, an item that is known for it's stable price of around $5, dipped down to $4.20 at it's lowest point on July 3rd, 2016, the same day that H3H3's video "Deception, Lies, and CSGO" was uploaded during the heart of the TmarTn scandal. But today, it is trading for $7.62. Virtual items still have little regulation in the United States. You can buy a Counter Strike skin from one site and then gamble it on another without having to verify your age or identity. Whether that's good or bad is up to you. But for now, anyway, it's still a Wild West. Jimmy Nichols - 3/5/2017

item.title: Beginnnings
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.content:encoded:
My PC background information.

Ever since I started tinkering with computers from a young age. I have always used and experienced a diverse choice of computer processors. I started out with a Mobile Pentium II chip on my IBM Laptop sporting Windows 98 (Second Edition might I add!). Despite running at only 333MHz, it was a workhorse of a chip when coupled with 64MB of RAM, the perfect fit for my IBM ThinkPad 390E. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1024"] The ThinkPad 390E was a great laptop, greater still when you got it for free![/caption] From then onwards, I disassembled and rebuilt multiple computers which my dad managed to snag from his work's PC disposal program. These computers came with CPUs ranging from the rare Cyrix 586 all the way to IBM PowerPC chips, maybe even a UltraSPARC II somewhere in there on a lucky day. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="2720"] Some of the CPUs I was lucky enough to mess around with![/caption]   In the golden age of Windows XP, I used an Athlon 64 based system with a whopping 2GB of RAM. But this was short-lived in my upgrade to a Core 2 Duo for the all new Windows Vista. Eventually I settled on a Core 2 Quad system with 6GB of RAM running the infamous Windows XP 64 Bit edition. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1024"] Not many people got to experience the awesome power of having 2 version of IE6.[/caption]

item.title: Cant afford the AMD Ryzen 3 1200?
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.content:encoded: Does AMD have a trick up it's sleeve to stay the king of budget builds? AMD's brand new platform, AM4 has been out for a few months now. Whilst many people believe that it had a rocky start, it has more than proven itself as a compelling upgrade path for existing AMD users on the previous AM3+ platform that dates all the way back to 2011. AM4 has also proven itself to be an awesome platform for Intel users who seek more multi-threaded performance or a product that is much better value for money and has a proven longevity over comparable Intel processors and chipsets. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1133"] A comparison of the new AM4 motherboard chipset options.[/caption] However, the main problem for many AMD stakeholders like myself is the price of upgrading from an AM3/+ CPU based system to the brand new Zen architecture. When upgrading, the user would have to purchase a brand new motherboard, processor, and RAM to go with the system. Not even a previous AM3/+ cooler could be repurposed for use with a new AM4 system due to the changes in the cooler mounting and socket design of the new Zen chips. You also have to bear in mind that the previous sweet-spot CPU for the AM3+ platform was by far the AMD FX8350 chip that offered excellent value for money at around 100 GBP. Now with the brand new platform, the lowest end Ryzen Chip, The Ryzen R3 1200 costs around the same, 100. slowly moving people off AM3 by changing am3 socket CPUs to am4 socket CPUs, no overhaul to speak of yet..... tbc

item.title: The 1060 3GB from NVidia why does it exist?
item.dc:creator: fedginator
item.content:encoded:
Its been about a year since the 1060 3 GB launched, yet it remains an enigma. Quite regularly the question of the 4GB 1050 Ti vs the 1060 3GB is raised by people being confused by the apparent overlap.

Ill start with what the 1060 is. The 1060 6GB uses the full GP106 die 1280 CUDA cores across 10 SMs, and a 192 bit memory bus with 6GB of VRAM. So far, so good. The 3GB model drops one SM (down to 9 with 1152 CUDA cores) and has only half the VRAM.

 

The loss of CUDA cores

Ill start with the loss in CUDA cores the reasoning here can be summed up in one word: binning. TSMC (who make most Pascal GPUs) just like all silicon manufacturers are not perfect the 16 nm process they use sometimes has errors. And these errors often restrict the function of the chip so as is ubiquitous in the tech industry the malfunctioning area is fused off and its sold as a cheaper chip.

This is called binning its why a 1070 is different to a 1080, why a 7700k is different from a Pentium G4560 and why a RX 470 is different from an RX 480. Any GP106 dies with errors simply have a SM disabled and shipped as the 3GB variant.

[caption id="attachment_728" align="alignnone" width="525"] Difference between the 2 1060 versions, showing how one SM is disabled[/caption] Does the loss of the single SM make much difference? Not really. it's 10% of shaders and most games don't utilise shaders that much. Will it have an impact? Of course, but it isn't crippling anything.

But the VRAM!

Well lets get into why this question is so often asked: Why does the 3GB 1060 have less VRAM than the 1050Ti? The answer to this lies in the memory bus layout of both chips hold on tight, were going on a deep(ish) dive into how video memory functions.

GDDR5 is shorthand for Double Data Rate type 5 synchronous Graphics random-access memory - a bit of a mouthful to be sure. But as with almost all graphics card components it is heavily standardised. GDDR5 always has 170 (67 of which are signal) pins, a prefetch of 8n and uses up to a 32 bit memory bus. Its the latter that matters from the 1060 situation as the 1060 has a 192 bit memory bus that means 6 individual 32 bit memory controllers for each of the 6 chips. No matter what card you have you can do the same test: divide your memory bus width by 32 to find the number of GDDR5 chips on your card.

  [caption id="attachment_727" align="alignleft" width="505"] Notice the 6 GDDR5 chips on this Gainward 1060 PCB.[/caption]              

Atfirst theimplications of this are not clear, however to maintain consistent memory bandwidth all chips need to be the same size, and after the scandal regarding memory speed and bandwidth on the GTX 970 Im pretty sure Nvidia have no interest in doing something like that again. That leaves a few options.

   

The largest GDDR5 chipsavailable are 8Gb (or 1GB) meaning the max possible is 6GB, whereas the smallest are 1Gb (1/8GB) ascending in a scale of powers of 2. Knowing this the set of possible values on a 192 bit bus are: 0.75GB, 1.5GB, 3GB and 6GB.

It is worth it?

So now you know why the 1060 3GB exists, but should you buy it over the 1050 Ti?

YES! Dont listen to what people tell you on forums about the VRAM holding it back. Even though VRAM is limited the 1060 3GB is still comfortably ahead in the vast majority of cases. With RX 580 pricing still sky high due to cryptomining then 1060 3GB is among the best price to performance card available. Regardless of VRAM.

item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded:
After \textit{The Commerce} ran aground, Riley and his crew were immediately plundered and ransacked by a tribe of Sahrawis. With their lives and freedoms at stake from the Sahrawis, Riley uses one of the older crew members as a decoy and escapes with the rest of the crew within inches of their lives. Using one of the brig's lifeboats they sailed along the coast in dangerous waters. It was at this time the men began to experience the extremes of thirst and hunger that would stick with them throughout the rest of the journey. Drinking their own urine and eating minuscule rations of salt pork they made it on a seeming safe land where they were immediately found by a more civilized tribe of Sahrawis known as the Oulad Bou Sbaa. A member of the tribe takes ownership of them as slaves. They are stripped of all their belongings including their clothing and now travel along the tribe. After several weeks of starvation, travel injury, and sunburn, Oulad Bou Sbaa came into contact with a tradesman, Sidi Hamet.
Riley had learned to speak and understand enough Arabic to communicate with the merchant so he explained his situation to him. Sidi Hamet sympathized with Riley and swore to him that he will be back safely with his family one day. A deal was made between Riley and Hamet that if Hamet buys Riley and some of his crewmen, Riley will get a '\textit{friend of his}' in Swearah to repay Hamet for the costs of the purchase, the costs of provisions, an additional fee, and two double-barrelled muskets. If Riley is unable to hold his side of the deal Hamet would cut his throat and sell his crew for as much as possible to the south. The truth was Riley did not have any friends he knew in Swearah, yet he managed to convince Hamet, a cunning salesman, that he was speaking the truth.
Sidi Hamet saw this deal as an opportunity to be able to pay off his debt to his father-in-law, Sheikh Ali. Ali is the leader of a large tribe and has considerable power. Riley and Hamet develop a strong friendship through their travels to the northern town of Swearah. After a difficult, risky, and seemingly endless journey, Hamet gives Riley the names of all the consuls in Swearah, asking him to point out which one he knew. Riley pointed to William Wilshire because it was a western sounding name. Riley carefully wrote a letter to Wilshire explaining the situation and pleading for his help. Hamet and a companion took off to Swearah to deliver the letter, leaving the crew in a camp with his brother. Fortunately for the men of \textit{The Commerce}, William knew of the sufferings of western slaves on the Sahara and obtained the money needed to pay Sidi Hamet.
During this time, complications did arise. Sheikh Ali arrived and found out about the Christians that Hamet had in his possession. Sheikh Ali plotted to take the slaves for himself but after a long struggle and a trip to another town --- thanks to Riley's social abilities --- Hamet and the crew were triumphant. Riley and his men made it to Swearah and were given a warm welcome by the British consul William Wilshire. Wilshire also sent out for the remaining of the crew. The majority of the men were reunited. Sidi Hamet also went in search for more crew members, unfortunately, he was killed protecting the men from a group of thieves who demanded that he give them the crew members (Those crew members did make it home safely, however).
The rest is history. Riley goes on to oppose slavery in the United States, citing that the very word fills him with discomfort. One retelling of the story ends up inspiring U.S. President Abraham Lincoln's campaign and policies against slavery.
\subsection*{About The Insight and Knowledge The Book Provides} \paragraph*{} The primary feature that distinguishes Skeletons On The Zahara from previous reiterations of Captain Riley's story is the extensive research and elaboration done on the author's part. Dean King traveled to the Sahara before writing the book and attempted to follow through Riley's path. This gave King a plethora of insight into the journey never before seen. He points out certain areas where Riley was likely mistaken about his whereabouts. The book also cross-references information from other accounts of westerners being sold into slavery in the area which confirm many things that were said to have happened. We also get several explanations for the way the Sahrawis behaved based on their culture and religion. All of this in addition to countless other '\textit{fun facts}' throughout the story jumping to past and future events that are connected. Skeletons On The Zahara is truly the ultimate retelling of the story.

item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded:
# Kamina [](logo/kamina_logo.svg) [//]: # (This and the logo line are comments for Ziad to uncomment when he edits because) [//]: # (he likes to see the pretty logo in pycharm when he edits the docs uwu )

Nice logo amirite. ## Overview **Kamina** is an IPFS-based, decentralized social network with free speech in mind... The social network is divided into communities, each with its independent governing system. ## Vision We want to develop a decentralized social network, that gives control to its users over their own personal information. Our decision to start this idea stemmed from many events in which Facebook has been mistreating our personal data, the Cambridge Analytica incident being an example, however, it is safe to say that the fact that Facebook has been selling all our data to advertisers and the general idea that centralized services that are not paid for tend to use this business model is plenty reason to want a decentralized alternative. Many similar products have been made to replace other services in this same manner. ## Design Decisions and Technicalities *Kamina* aims to be as decentralized as possible without becoming a full-blown 'distributed system'. After analyzing the possible technologies that could help us reach this objective, we've found out that **IPFS**, while still being in its infancy, is a good option to store information for *Kamina*. We chose Python3 because it is cross-platform, easy to learn and work with, and has a large community. *Kamina* will be split into 3 separate components that will communicate with each other. - ***Kamina Community*** - ***Kamina User*** - ***Kamina Search*** The APIs for each component will be implemented in Flask and the front end of each will be implemented using VueJS. ### Kamina Community ***Kamina Community*** is, as the name suggests, where all the users interact and communicate. - Each ***Kamina Community*** instance has a single, broad or otherwise, discussion topic much in the same way you can have groups for different topics and interests on Facebook and other social networks. - Anyone can access and start using a ***Kamina Community*** instance, but the user is be limited to what it can do. + In order to access all the functionality of the instance, the user has to register into that community. + The registration requires the user to download and start a ***Kamina User*** instance on their device. This is an example of what a ***Kamina Community*** instance would look like. ![community-preview](./img/preview.png) ### Kamina User This is where all the user information is stored and managed. - In order to give the user full control over their information, the information is stored on the user's device. - The user must download and initialize a user instance on their device and can then register into any existing ***Kamina Community*** instance. - The instance exposes an API for the ***Kamina Community*** instance to exchange information with. ### Kamina Search ***Kamina Search*** is a system allows the user to access information from a ***Kamina Community*** instance. - It stores backup data from ***Kamina Community*** instances in case the data disappears. - Works similar to Mastodon search instances. [search page](https://instances.social/list#lang=&allowed=&prohibited=&users=) - The user can access the content of a ***Kamina Community*** up until the date of the creation of the backup stored. ## How to contribute ### Getting Started * Create a GitHub account or use an existing one. * Create an issue in the corresponding project (community, user, search, etc.) if one does not already exist. - Clearly describe the issue including steps to reproduce if it is a bug. - Make sure to add the earliest version that contains that issue. * Fork the repository on GitHub. ### Making Changes * Create a new branch from where you will base your work. * Make commits of logical and atomic units. * Be sure you are following pep-8 when writing the code. ### Submitting Changes * Push your changes to a branch in your fork of the repository. * Before submitting a pull request: - Run pylint in all the files you have modified - Describe the changes you've made as verbose as possible * Submit a pull request to the project's repository. * If after 2 weeks of giving feedback there is no activity, the pull request will be closed. ### Additional Resources * [pylint](https://www.pylint.org/) * [PEP 8](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/)

item.title: Is this the ULTIMATE 1080Ti??!??!?!?!?!
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.content:encoded: Lets face it, GPU's, whilst performing vastly differently in gaming and production workloads, all look similar from the outside. A PCB, PCIe Slot, Power Connector and a few fans. Maybe even a backplate if your lucky or a waterblock if you are adventurous. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="650"] Booooooooring....[/caption] But this is where Colourful, the little-known manufacturer of surprisingly good GPUs and Motherboards is looking to change the game. Following the announcement of the new 1080Ti by NVidia, Coloruful has been working on its unique new "IGame 1080Ti". It features a new cooler design dubbed "Shark Bionics" featuring three 92mm red backlit fans to ensure that the card stays cool, even under the most extreme overclocks. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="2000"] Is this sexier that a custom loop?[/caption] It also features one of the most advanced power deliver systems ever on a GPU with it's 16+2 phase power system, the only other card that features this same power delivery system is ZOTAC 's EXTREME range of GPUs. Whilst this new system may not be the most useful for the average gamer, it should prove for some interesting overclocking results on LN2 due to this more stable power delivery system that should be able to power a plethora of high frequency overclocks! [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="841"] The 16+2 phase power delivery system :O[/caption] But now we move on to the final killer feature, an LCD. Colourful has stated that this "game-changing" LCD will display useful information to the user such as; clock speed, GPU usage, temperature and fan tachometers. Certainly a useful feature for those uses who would rather quickly glance through the side panel of their case to check readings rather thanruining a game with overlays or having to tab out to navigate menus just to find this information. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="2000"] Yes, that is an LCD screen on top of a GPU!!!![/caption] I would go as far as to say that, a card like this with it defined colour scheme and innovation however crazy is much more interesting and appealing to me then a neutral looking card caked in RGB LEDs, a market trend that to me seems overrated and ultimately destroys careful colour coordination that system builders do to ensure the most aesthetically pleasing system possible. I think that other manufactures should take a leaf out of colourful's book and make a product that is unique and potentially useful. Rather than following a market trend, why not create a new one. Personally I am not sure whether or notthe 16+2 phase power deliverydesign or the revolutionising LCD will make the most difference to me, as the end user, however what I can tell you is that if money was no objection and I was in the market for a 1080Ti, this is the one that I would definitely invest in!

Gaming PCs are easily accessible on line. With iBUYPOWER, Staples, Best Buy, and other retailers, buying a pre-built gaming PC seems like a no-brainer. item.title: INSANE 32 Core Skylake Extreme CPU revealed!
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.content:encoded: With all the recent hype around Ryzen and Kaby Lake, many enthusiasts have noticed the lack of any new products in the HEDT (High End Desktop Platform) line for enthusiasts who require more CPU power than the gaming optimised Kaby Lake series can offer for content creators and other areas where a high power CPU is beneficial. Whilst Ryzen 7 chips are infact solid contenders in the workstation industry, a statement you have to agree with no matter which side you support. They were realistically marketed to the wrong audience, gamers, and with AMD now notorious for failing to meet expectations, many power users have expressed reluctancy to switch to a new system in fear of the many launch day and other bugs that plauged the launch of Ryzen. This is where intel steps in with it's Skylake-EP architecture and the X299 chipset from intel to replace the X99 chipset and the Broadwell-E Socket LGA 2011-3 for a much larger LGA 3647 socket to allow for a much higher bandwidth between the CPU and the chipset for upcoming features such as AXV 512, 6 Channel memory and Intel 100G Omni-Path interconnects to allow blazing fast speeds between 8 CPUs on a motherboard which could prove revolutionising to the server market place that intel has always dominated. This change of platform and infrastructure is surely a sign of good things to come meaning that the X299 platform and Skylake-E/X CPUs will likely be one of the biggest and most inovative launches by intel in recent times compared to the more consumer grade hardware that only sees a mere 5% improvement across generations, a number which intel knows it can easily sell with the lack of current competition for consumer grade CPUs. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="800"] LGA 3647 Socket vs LGA 2011 CPU[/caption]   Along with this new chipset and supporting infrastructure, it has been revealed that a 32 Core Skylake CPU dubbed "Purley" (Likely the new E5-2699V5 chip ) is in the works. It has not be said what range the CPU will come under but it is almost certainly a Xeon chip hence its high core count and low base frequency of 2.1Ghz. It has managed to hit some crazy numbers in geekbench testing, with a multicore score of 49,647, hitting 3,526 when it came to single-core performance. The reason for this new chip is likely a retaliation from Intel who potentially fear for their position in the datacentre (which they almost completely domiate) following the announcment of AMD's 32C/64T Naples CPU which features 8 memory channels and its 128 lane Infinity Fabric to rival intel Omni-Path and up to 128 PCIE Gen 3 lanes to increase potential and flexibilty of the new platform compared to the 80 pcie lanes of the highest end Intel Xeon E5-2699 V4 Chip that featurs 12 less cores than the new AMD alternative. Intel's 32 core chip to compete with AMD's new Naple's CPU shows a huge jump over intels previous generation E5-2699V4, gaining an extra 10 cores compared to the regular 2 core increments that Intel regularly tease each year. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="554"] Who will the next generation data centre choose; Intel or AMD?[/caption] The fact that data centre dominating Intel are tensing ready to release a rival chip to AMD's new pickings shows that no matter what side you support, it is hard to argue against the fact that competition really does drive innovation for both sides, leading to better, cheaper, more efficient and more powerful chips for the end user, a benefit that nobody can be against.

item.title: New Operation in CS:GO?
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded: A week ago on March 15th, 2017, Valve released a new update for CS:GO, adding the new map Canals as well as the new Spectrum weapon case containing 17 new weapon skins, and the second generation of knives in the Chroma finishes. But that's not all that was included in the update. On March 16th YouTube personality McSkillet revealed that in the files of the game after the update, there is an image that appears to be the map group image for the supposed operation maps for selecting which group to search for a server in when playing the Deathmatch and Casual game modes, as well as images for each of the supposed maps when selecting a map to play a Competitive game on in his video titled "CS:GO - OPERATION 8: MAPS LEAKED! (Next Operation Leak 2017)." This isn't the first time McSkillet has revealed information relating to an operation before. February 13th, 2016, he released a video titled "CS:GO - The Next Operation Maps" in which he gave viewers a look at of each of the maps that would later be included in the Operation Wildfire update, released on February 17th, 2016, and was the last Operation update in CS:GO. Counter Strike players have been long wondering when the next Operation update would be coming to Global Offensive, and with this information, hopefully the answer is "Soon" (in Valve time).

item.title: Congress Repeals Consumer Internet Protections, Allows ISPs to Sell Your Browsing History
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded: The House of Representatives and Senate have both voted to repeal ISP privacy rules that would require an explicit opt-in by customers to have their browsing history, as well as other private information, collected and sold. It is likely that President Trump will sign the legislation, as The White House has released a statement in support of it. You can see the Congressional bodies' votes here and here. If you want your browsing history to stay private, you're going to need to do more than browse in Incognito or a Private window. You're going to need to use a service called a Virtual Private Network (usually just referred to as a VPN). There are free VPN services, however, they are involved in scandals too often for some to be comfortable using them. You can find some good paid options in the VPN community on Reddit. Something that may surprise some readers is that Facebook and Google are already collecting your personal information to push targeted, more expensive ads to users. This was a cornerstone of Republican politicians' arguments to repeal the consumer protections, citing that ISPs were being treated differently than search engines and social networks. Other Republicans argued that it was outside the FCC's jurisdiction to regulate how ISPs can do business, and that this issue should be decided by the FTC, and that the protections would confuse customers. This of course calls into question whether or not we could see another Net Neutrality battle in the coming months, as the current administration fights to undermine consumer protections and industry regulations. You wouldn't find many people who actually support repealing Net Neutrality (probably about the same amount who supported repealing these consumer protections). But does the current administration even care?

item.title: 5 Worst Games at Launch
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded: Game companies have been more and more often pushing out broken, buggy games that weren't ready for the public. The most recent of these is EA's and Bioware's Mass Effect Andromeda, which was criticized for it's unsettlingly unrealistic facial animations, it's frequent, obvious bugs, and it's performance issues. But this isn't an uncommon occurrence in the game industry, and in the recent years we've seen quite a few triple A games (or at least games with triple A prices) be released in an almost unfinished state. So let's take a moment to reflect on these botched big game launches. 5 - SimCity (2013) SimCity's newest iteration released with always online DRM at a time when such DRM was very controversial, and in a single player game no less. EA claimed that it was necessary for the game's cloud computing features, and a reasonable anti-piracy measure. However, since then a SimCity dev has come forward and revealed that no computing is done server side for the actual simulation of the players' cities. 4 - Batman: Arkham Knight On release the game had immense framerate drops whenever the player character MOVED. People were reasonably upset, reviewers slammed the game, and Warner Brothers even had to pull the PC version of the game from sale to curb the outrage. 3 - Assassins Creed Unity Assassins Creed Unity on release was mired with graphics bugs. In the middle of a conversation, NPC's faces would simply disappear, leaving you talking to a disembodied set of dentures and eyes. Servers were sometimes unable to be reached, and so ingame loot boxes wouldn't work properly. While not the most broken game on this list, it was one of the most known of. 2 - Duke Nukem Forever Duke Nukem Forever was considered vaporware for over a decade. Some might say that it should've stayed that way. Although it was probably never going to live up to the expectations that people had after a decade long development cycle, even if the game wasn't a Duke Nukem game it would likely have been panned by reviewers and ignored by everyone else. Duke Nukem Forever was, more or less, a generic early 2010's FPS with a Duke Skin slapped on. A few well VOed one-liners weren't enough to save this game. 1 - No Man's Sky No Man's Sky was probably the most hyped game of 2016, with everyone from YouTube personalities to pop-news sites singing it's praises before release. The premise was very ambitious; 18 quintillion planets, each with their own procedurally generated landscape, color palette, and even life, a great secret to be discovered in the center of the galaxy once you reached it, and even the ability to see other players if you even managed to find each other in this massive universe. What we actually got was lackluster in comparison to what we had been shown (and to be honest, imagined the game to be). This article isn't to list off everything that was promised to be in the game that isn't, but suffice to say that it was a lot. And what was in the game, the differing planets and creatures, started to run together and all seem very similar after a few short hours. The project was ambitious, and perhaps it was that ambition that was it's downfall.

item.title: SSDs - Are They Worth the Price?
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded: Mechanical hard drives have been around for a long time, and the speeds of these drives are much slower than new SSDs or M.2 drives. Along with speed, the moving parts in an HDD increase the risk of possible failure and loss of data. After using an SSD for the first time, the difference is astronomical. Basic usage is much more responsive, and a game like Battlefield 4 opens in half the time. People never know how slow HDDs are until the switch to flash storage. SSDs are especially useful for reading and writing mass files to the drive. The only issue with Solid State Drives are the prices. For the same price of a 128GB SSD, a 1TB HDD can be purchased. For price/storage, an SSD is definitely not optimal at this time. However, are they still worth it, even with the expense? Maybe. As a storage drive, an SSD is usually not a good option. 128GB fills up far too fast, and for gamers and workstations, much more space is required. However, buying an SSD as a boot drive for Windows and essentials can increase speeds substantially. If you already have an HDD as a storage drive, an SSD is a great option for a speed boost to your PC. If you can afford getting a 1TB SSD, it would be a great investment. However, as a budget conscious builder, an SSD should only be purchased as a boot drive. Check out this video for speed comparisons between HDDs and SSDs: https://youtu.be/M3SXvlALn2U

item.title: Game Review: Ib
item.dc:creator: gann.danielle123
item.content:encoded:
Ib, oh my god, where to start. Ever wanted to be a little girl? Heres your chance. Ib is a puzzle/adventure RPG. Ib takes you into the mind of a child, where you explore an art gallery by yourself and away from the safety of your parents, before entering a world completely whimsical. Great experience for a first-time art gallery visitor, am I right?

Being trapped in a dark, and scary gallery alone can definitely bring out the worst in people, seeing as your life depends on how many rose petals you have, and whether or not a painting or sculpture is going to attack you from around that corner.

The health system is pretty interesting as well, you have to find vases around the gallery that are filled with water, and you have to place your rose in it. Back to the game itself, Ib allows creativity, and imagination as you play.

My thoughts on Ib, when I first played it years ago, involved me wondering what the heck just happened. Do something wrong and its an instant butterfly effect. You wander around halls, figuring out puzzles, and fending off many different types of animated art gallery objects. I bet you that eye drawn on the wall will blink.

Its not all bad, little ways into the game you will meet the secondary protagonist, Garry. Garry will appoint himself as your(Sort of) caretaker. He will protect you as much as he can from the evil within the gallery. He also has a rose, that you have to fight a painting for.

The character setup is pretty good, Garry comes off as a sort of scaredy cat teenager, while Ib is a reserved little girl. You, however, see the childlike features in Ib when she openly trusts another person she meets in the Gallery, Mary. Mary openly dislikes Garry, and vise versa. The moment you meet her, you can tell something just isnt right.

That becomes even more clear as you are separated from Garry, and stuck with Mary. Throughout the game, you are forced to choose who to trust, and the endings will all depend on that. There are seven different endings and many variations. I recommend saving, a lot.

Im not going to give away the endings, in case anyone wants a more spoiler-free environment, but I will say one thing, do not lose your rose.

Download the game here

item.title: New CS:GO Update Makes Negev $2,000 and Breaks Cache Textures
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded: A new CS:GO update released earlier today re-added the Negev to the game. The gun, along with the R8 revolver, was removed from the competitive matchmaking mode of the game to be reworked and given a place in the CS:GO meta. The gun now costs $2,000, the same as the Galil assault rifle and the XM1014 shotgun. The first twenty or so rounds are incredibly inaccurate, but it becomes much more predictable as you shoot. After some initial testing, this author finds that the Negev is much worse in competitive. You would be served much better purchasing a Famas, Galil, or even a UMP. In Counter Strike there just aren't a lot of situations that a gun with an unpredictable recoil pattern is useful. The update also updated textures on the map Cache. While the map looks better in some areas, adding in little nooks and crannies that were just walls before, other areas are just completely black, like the T side garage doors, and the hammer and sickle on the way to B site from T spawn, along with part of the wall below it. The update also mangled the texture on the side of the Garage. It may have been intended to be reflective, and while it still somewhat retains a reflective effect, it it very low quality. The R8 Revolver also sees a return to the competitive game mode, at a price of $700. This makes the gun buyable on pistol rounds, which it previously was not. In addition the R8 Revolver received a buff, reducing the amount of time it takes to fire an accurate shot. This author has not yet seen the gun used in-game or used it himself in a competitive matchmaking game. The addition of these two weapons is only temporary, and likely we will see them be removed to be tweaked more in the coming weeks.

item.title: Upgrade Your PC for Free! THE POWER OF OVERCLOCKING
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded:
Overclocking. We've all heard of YouTubers and PC Enthusiasts pushing their CPUs, GPUs, and RAM past the speed they're shipped at. Simply put, overclocking is increasing the speed, usually in Ghz, at which your hardware operates. This, in turn, will force your hardware to run faster. This can improve the computer's work in all tasks!

Of course, it may seem quite scary to increase the speed of your hardware past it's orginal intentions. Some myths related to overclocking include:

  • Expensive hardware is required (PSU, CPU Cooler, Water Cooling, etc.)
This is certainly not true. I recently overclocked my Pentium G3258 from 3.2Ghz to 4.0Ghz with nothing but a $30 CPU cooler (Hyper T4). I also use a run of the mill EVGA power supply. Unless extreme overclocking is desired, there is almost never a need for anything more powerful than a Hyper 212 Evo.
  • Your PC will be permanently damaged
When overclocking, you do run the small risk of damaging components. However, with research and proper testing, the chances are very,very low. With MSI Afterburner, you can easily reset your GPU to stock speeds. CPUs are a bit more difficult, but removing the BIOS Chip or CPU itself usually solves the problem. Constant testing will allow the best overclock. Going too far without testingcandefinitelyfry something. The trick is to constantly check temperatures while overclocking.
  • Benefits aren't worth it
Out of all the myths of overclocking, this is the WORST. Check any YouTube video or benchmark test, and you'll see. People gain anywhere from 5-20 fps simply by overclocking their hardware. An R9 270x can run as good, or even better than an R9 280 if a good overclock is made. Not overclocking hardware that can be overclocked is leaving free performance on the table, as Jay says. Personally, I gained over 10FPS in some games after OCing my Pentium G3258.
  • Reduce the life of your hardware
This is the only part that reigns somewhat true to overclocking downsides. However, it may not even be considered a downside. Your CPU's life may be cut down from 15 years to 10, give or take, but will you use that CPU for 10 years? Squeezing the extra performance may limit the lifespan, but chances are, the amount you removing will probably not be noticed by you. There are many tutorials and videos on YouTube discussing overclocking.JayzTwoCents in particular has a lot of great points on overclocking. Overclocking is almost always beneficial to the user. Without proper research, testing or knowledge, youwilldamage your hardware. Make sure you check tutorials, test and monitor along the way, and be smart if you want the best, safe overclock. Ask a knowledgable friend to be there while you do it. Lastly, all hardware is different. Thesilicon lottery is a means of saying how lucky someone was with their hardware. Someone may be able to put out 5Ghz out of their 4790K while barely adjusting voltage, and others will barely be able to get 4.5Ghz. The trick is to test personally. Some good software when OCing: MSI Afterburner, Prime95, HWMonitor, and more! [caption id="attachment_336" align="alignnone" width="300"] MSI afterburner[/caption]

item.title: Top 5 FREE Steam Games!!!
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.content:encoded: Lets face it, gaming is an expensive hobby, hardware is expensive and new games often sell for upwards of $60 without factoring in the multiple DLC's that many developers include in a desperate bid to squeeze more money out of the unsuspecting consumer. This is why I recommend occasionally taking a step back from Triple A titles and having a look at some of the best free games that are available on the PC platform, whilst not all of them are good, many put more premium titles to shame and are almost guaranteed future classics. 1. War Thunder [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1024"] Insane Graphics, Cross Compatibility and Simulation Settings. Is this FREE game perfect?[/caption] War thunder is an increasingly popular World War 2 style MMO. It boasts its extremely optimised gameplay that provides stunning visuals for weaker PC's and its settings that range from arcade style to deep simulation to make the game accessible to anyone. Whilst it can take a long time to research new aircraft, it definitely is not a problem due to the games addictiveness that can place anyone in command of a plane or tank in the depth of World War 2. 2. Team Fortress 2 [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="460"] Almost certainly the best arcade style shooter to date![/caption] Anyone who has been a PC gamer for a reasonable amount of time will have heard of Team Fortress 2 (TF2), it has attained an almost legendary status with pc gamers for its fast paced gameplay and fun community. It is not the newest game as it this year celebrates it 10 year anniversary but for a 10 year old game it is more than impressive due to its almost always full lobbies and active developer community that carry on working on this game to date. It may not be as popular as Overwatch, but it definitely paved the way for that genre, hence why any steam library without this game is practically bare. 3. DOTA 2 [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1191"] The F2P ESports Sensation![/caption] DOTA 2 (Defence of the Ancients) is another title that should be familiar to any long term PC Gamer. It is one of the most popular MOBA games (Multiple Online Battle Arena) played at the highest ESports level due to its fast paced, tactical gameplay that adds to the gamelongevity and competiveness. Its RTS roots and teamwork based gameplay that require effective communication and coordination make this game one of the most exciting and competitive to date. 4. Planetside 2 [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1920"] Arguably the best F2P shooter?[/caption] PlanetSide 2 is afree to playMMOFPSreleased in November 2012, It is a sequel of PlanetSide, which originally released in 2003, it falls into the SCI-FI genre andfeatures everything you could ever want in a FPS gamefrom jump packs to full-scale vehicles, Planetside 2 doesnt do combat on the small or simplistic level. It has a large active community fan base and the developers are very active making this game a worthy addition to any steam library. The game has a pretty steep learning curve making it hell for new players, but once you get more familiar with the game, it is more rewarding than most AAA shooter games and their expensive DLC's that shows that price does not always reflect quality. 5. Paladins [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="690"] Is this game the poor mans Overwatch?[/caption] Paladins is an increasingly popular MOBA game(Massive online battle arena) that boasts team based tactical gameplay. The objective is to destroy the enemy team and base using a variety or different character classes. Paladins predates and shares many characteristics with the late Overwatch which it has been criticized for its cost, if you are unsure whether or not you wantto pickup Overwatch, play this game first. Its simplistic gameplay and objective makes it an extremely fun game to play every once ina while. This is the first article on the best F2P Steam games, if you want another article on some more games or if you have some recommendations, leave a comment down below.

item.title: One of the Most Realistic Shooters Around - Insurgency
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded:
I've been a fan of first person shooters for over 6 years now. I've played COD, Battlefield, CS:GO, and more in terms of competitive games. All these games have their own pros and cons, and they definitely have their own appeal group. However, I've stumbled across a first person shooter that's been around for quite some time, but has a player-base of less than 3000 people in many cases. It cost me only $5 on the steam sale, and it's hands down, my favorite competitive FPS game at this time.

Insurgency."Take to the streets for intense close quarters combat, where a team's survival depends upon securing crucial strongholds and destroying enemy supply in this multiplayer and cooperative Source Engine based experience." This is one of the most realistic shooters around. If you fire only two bullets in the right place, you'll get the kill. You won't need to waste 5 bullets on one person anymore. On the spectrum of competitive games, it's something of a mix between Battlefield and CS:GO. For a game created with the Source Engline, it's absolutely stunning in terms of visuals. With almost 20 different maps, and servers of up to 32 players, you'll have a blast with Insurgency. Insurgency takes a lot of focus and quick decisions as you try to counter your enemies, or gain objectives, depending on the game mode. It's heavily based on your team, so you'll have to co-ordinate to be successful. You will often be killed by someone lurking in the shadows, or hiding in a building in the distance, and it will take time to find all the spots to look out for while playing. You can also make many tweaks to your soldier, from the weapon of choice, to how many weapons to carry. This will all affect how effective you are, your position, and how fast you can move. Insurgency doesn't have what almost every other shooter does. There isn't much reward to grinding other than knowing you're one of the best. You can't run and gun, and you'll often find yourself sitting, waiting, and watching. When you play Insurgency, you need to think on the fly, and make the right decisions, or youwillend up dead. You can often find the game on sale for $5 or less. Even at the full price, you can get hundreds of hours of enjoyment with friends, or on your own with Insurgency. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys shooters, and wants a more realistic experience.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: One of the greatest, and most realistic shooters on the PC. Insurgency is hands down, one of the most realistic, and fun shooters on the PC.

item.title: Eventually Obsolete: eMachines' Acquisition and Fall
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded: When I was a kid, my family's first computer was a beige eMachines tower that sat in the living room. It was attached to a CRT monitor that weighed nearly as much as I did. We didn't have internet service, it wasn't available until we moved to a new house a couple years later. But, I do remember spending hours and hours playing edutainment games and solitaire on it. If you walk into any computer shop, browse any online retailer that sells computers, you won't see any eMachines. So that begs the question, what happened to them? eMachines was founded in September 1998 as a low-end, budget computer manufacturer. They offered computers for under $400 at a time when you were likely to pay $1,000 for an entry level PC. They later went on to release the T6000, the first mass-marketed AMD Athlon 64 based PC. eMachines largely faded away from the public eye after that, being unremarkable until they were bought out by Gateway for $262 million in 2004. The brand was later discontinued at CES 2013. Gateway is now in the same boat as eMachines. Gone from the shelves of PC stores and relegated to used eBay listings and delusional Craigslist posts. Gateway was founded in September of 1985 as Gateway 2000. They later rebranded themselves as just Gateway in 1998. The fledgling computer company focused on marketing itself as a simpler, easier to use and understand PC. They used their roots as a business started in a barn in Iowa to make people believe they're a simple, down to earth computer company. Gateway had attempted some groundbreaking stuff during their height, including an early precursor to modern media PCs; The Destination. They were also the first company to make an optical drive standard on all their machines, and release a sub-$1,000 name-brand personal computer: The Astro. Gateway fell on hard times after the Dot Com Bubble Burst though, and despite efforts to become profitable again, they were acquired by Acer in 2007. Today, no new Gateway computers are being manufactured. And so these computer manufacturers become icons of a bygone era. Nostalgic relics for people at the forefront of computer technology and the internet when they were first relevant and mainstream.

item.title: Intel Re-brands Xeon chips! | An overview of the new naming scheme
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.content:encoded: For just over 5 years Intel has had a very simple andconvenient naming scheme for its server and desktop CPU lineup. In desktop chips we get the i3, i5 and i7 with the latter being the most powerful class of CPUs with the i3 being the weakest (Save for Pentium and Celerons). Then in the enterprise lineup we get the Xeon E3 (Which are actually rebranded i7's minus the graphics chip) , E5 and E7 which again get more powerful as the number increases. Then the first digit of the second number (e.g. E3-1220v4, E5-2670v1, E7-8800v4) represents how many processors are supported in the same system, therefore the E3 supports only 1 Socket, the E5 with 1 or 2 and finally the E7 with 8,4,2 or 1 sockets. Then finally the last number represents the generation (A Xeon E3-1220v6 is a Kaby Lake series Xeon). [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="450"] Intel's slightly less confusing naming scheme[/caption] Whilst this may sound confusing, it is actually a very efficient naming scheme that is easy to remember and understand, which is especially useful when you are ordering CPUs for potentially thousands of system if you are responsible for upgrade and update cycles in a data centre environment. However, after everybody has finally sussed out the initially confusing name scheme of the Xeon lineup, Intel decides to change the name scheme up to make things indefinitely confusing. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="640"] What is happening at Intel?!?!?!?[/caption] The top 14 Xeon chips offered are now dubbed "Xeon Platinum" with model numbers in the 8000s. These chips are expected to replace the Xeon E7 series which are the most powerful and feature filled chips that Intel offers. The next 20 CPUs are dubbed "Xeon Gold" which features model numbers 5000 - 6000, potentially suggesting that this no longer represents the amount of supported CPU sockets in a system, which is going to be very confusing for many System Admins. Also notice that some Chips have the suffix "M" or "T". "T" potentially represents low power as they have lower clock speeds, however what nobody can agree on is what "M" stands for, mobile? [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="800"] A Xeon D chip Vs the upcoming Skylake-SP server socket (LGA3647)[/caption] Apart from these confusing name scheme changes, it has also been noted that these new chips feature the AVX512 instruction set, something not found in any consumer chips by Intel, suggesting that these new CPUs are the long awaited Skylake-SP chips, therefore Skylake-X could carry the "Silver" and "Bronze" name if intel so decided. That however would make "Bronze" CPUs the same as high end consumer i7 chips, so then what would we call the poor Pentium and Celerons CPUs that once again end up at the bottom of the pile of Intel' changing priorities? Now all we are waiting for is AMD Naples to roll on with its supposed higher bandwidth, core count for a lower price!

item.title: The Reality of Ultra Settings | PC Upgrading
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded: Let's get right to the point. The PC gives you more customization in all ways when compared with consoles. This includes hardware of choice, in-game settings, mods, and so much more! However, the need for PC gamers to achieve ultra settings at 60FPS, or more, depending on the person, is almost like a disease. Even GTX 1080Tis aren't capable of running games COMPLETELY cranked up, especially with special qualities such as NVIDIA Hairworks. You might expect to run these games completely maxed out due to the sheer amount of money spent on the hardware, but in reality, developers don't see it that way. They create those crazy settings for people with crazy builds, and even to future proof it in a sense. Sure, you can't max out TW3 at 4K 60FPS with your 1070, but once you upgrade again a few years down the line, there's a good chance that it will be easy. The point is, don't worry too much if you can't completely max out your games. You don't need to upgrade just because you can't achieve 60FPS, or completely maxed out settings. Spend time adjusting your settings, and you'll surely find something enjoyable. A good rule of thumb is to upgrade your graphics cards every 2-4 years. Of course, if you can afford to, or just really want to upgrade every generation, more power to you!   Check out my take on this:https://goo.gl/g7yxN6

item.title: Windows RT - Microsoft's largest failure..
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.content:encoded:
A select few of you may remember Windows RT, you have even bought an RT machine. In fact most PC users will have heard of it after Microsoft's substantial advertising scheme that was full of misinformation and lies in general.

What it is

Windows RT (Runtime) was a slimmed down version of Windows 8 (Which itself was a slimmed down rebuild of the Windows 7 OS),designed to run on ARMCPU's as opposed to the "obsolete, inefficient and slow" x86_64 standard desktop architecture. In theory it was a great idea, Manufactures could use dirt cheap ARM CPUs, some Flash Storage and whatever cheap components they could get their hands on. It could be flashed to Windows RT and then sold to the consumer who would think that it was a bargain, afamiliar to use Windows PC that could be used as a tablet as well, cool? [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="580"] Overhyped, under powered and just a general failure...[/caption]

What was wrong with Windows RT

However they could not be more wrong! Many users found that you could not install normal PC apps, only ones from the extremely lacking Microsoft "Store". Users were also limited to using Internet Explorer as their browser! Microsoft tried to monopolise the tablet market, tried to steal a large chunk of the market share from Apple with its Surface RT book and to be honest the RT book wasa fairly nice machine, it actually was fast and it had great build quality, however its major flaw was the Microsoft was hoping that the market would move to mobile (As did intel and many other companies), hence the touch optimised Metro UI of Windows 8. Of course this never happened, people never jumped on the bandwagon from their XP/7 desktops and laptops that in reality, just worked. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1366"] Metro, you either loved it or hated it, most likely hated it if you were using a proper PC[/caption] And this is why RT failed (And 8 for that matter), they tried to sell the Surface Book, an iPad competitor that's costs as much as a laptop, looks like a laptop but can't be loaded with normal programs, just vendor locked Microsoft Store junk. For many users the convertible aspect was just a gimmick. Especially considering that the typing keyboard was an extra 100 , a necessity for anybody that wanted to use this "PC".

The results

Overall the product was a joke and it needed up losing Microsoft $1.2 billion, about as much as they spent on advertising . The mobile market just wasn't there, and RT was a niche product, if people wanted mobile they used their phones/tablet, if they wanted a computer they used their laptop or desktop. The only areas that really benefitted for this product were in areas like health-care, but specialized software were needed and as you can guess, they didn't run on ARM, nor did any enterprise applications for that matter There were only a few successful mobile devices for this era in Microsoft's history, such as the Asus T100, a convertible laptop, tablet that ran FULL WINDOWS 8.1 and included a keyboard for only 240. It was a product that was successful because Asus actually knew where they were aiming it at, home users, most unlike its poor, unloved brother, the Surface RT. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="830"] A product that just worked, the ASUS T100.[/caption] Overall, the Windows 8 era, was a horrible era in my opinion, and I am sure that many people will agree. People were forced to use their desktops like tablets, and actual tablets just pretended to run windows, with miserable effort. Even Microsoft realised and hence launched Windows 8.1 to try and fix the instable and completely messed up windows ecosystem after destroying the functional XP for no valid reason and forcing the "Revolutionary" touch optimised Windows 8 on happy unsuspecting Windows 7 users.

Conclusion

Yes it did bring some innovation to the market, such as bringing x86 tablets to the mainstream, something that was really cool but ultimately a gimmick. It also made a few products that actually worked, it really made me love Asus (For then at least) for managing to create a successful product (The T100)through so much confusion, misunderstanding andbad cooperation between companies and the consumers at the time. Overall though, Microsoft made a big mistake, all Windows RT did was push X86 forwards, a fortunate benefit for us PC Gamers that were thought to become obsolete, but despite this, it was a mistake that myself as a Windows (andPartial Linux)user will never forget. Windows RT on Wikipedia

item.title: Low Tier Graphics Cards? NOPE!
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded: Computer components are expensive. A good mid-tier graphics card will easily set you back around $200, and that can really burn a hole through your wallet. While looking at the prices, a low power graphics card at only $60, or even $40 may catch your eye. It's significantly cheaper, and the box says it can play games. However, buying these low tier GPUs is the same thing as throwing money into a fire.PLEASE, DO NOT BUY LOW END GRAPHICS CARDS. What is a low-tier graphics card? You'd usually find these at your local computer retail store for significantly cheaper than other cards, and significantly smaller. While most GPUs are near the $200 price range, these low tier cards can be found for well over $100. Some examples of these cards include the GT 710, GT 730, etc. While the prices are very attractive, these cardsare notworth the money. As you can tell by these graphs, the GT 710 is among the worst performing GPUs one can buy. This card can be found from many retailers for $30-$60, but that would simply be throwing away $30. A step up from the low-tier range would be cards such as the GTX 1050 or RX 460. Choosing these graphics cards and paying slightly more will provide a significantlybetter gaming experience. They can also fit in almost any PC. To sum it up, save your money for a little longer, and spring for a higher end graphics card. Low-tier cards are simply not justifiable in any way. If you're looking to save even more money, check out the used market!The newly released GTX 1030 is not worth the price.

item.title: Game Review: Mad Father | An Adventure Horror RPG
item.dc:creator: gann.danielle123
item.content:encoded:
Summary of Mad Father

Looking for a murderous father in your area? Oh, do I havethe man for you. Mad Father is a German based game where you follow the life of a little girl named Aya. Aya is the daughter of ascientist. A scientist who also may or may not be a psychopath that you really should let die alone. Really want to die alone. Whatever though, I dont judge. Your whole goal in this game is to save your father from the experiments hes created. Who come back like that zombie from Hocus Pocus. Which he caused by murdering and angering a wholelot of people. Because of this, it makes it difficult for Aya. The story of my life.

[caption id="attachment_448" align="alignnone" width="300"] Home Screen - Mad Father[/caption] [caption id="attachment_452" align="alignnone" width="300"] Alfred Drevis[/caption]

Okay, onward. Mad Father is a single player puzzle/adventure/horror game. In which you go through your labyrinth of a mansion. Also holy cow, where did David Bowie come from. This mansion should not have this big of a basement anyway. As you go along, you realize just how many people have died to your Vaders chainsaw... Or hand, "Chainsaw" is cooler. Really, this is no spoiler, one second into the game and oh, someone died.

[caption id="attachment_449" align="alignnone" width="300"] Bathtub of blood - Mad Father[/caption]

Characters in Mad Father

[caption id="attachment_450" align="alignnone" width="200"] Aya Drevis - Mad Father[/caption]

Aya Drevis is the main character you play as throughout the whole game. There are some other people you play as, but really, they dont last long. Ill leave it to you to figure out what the hell all of these people are doing zombie-ing your house. Because of this, things get weird quickly. The saving system is pretty easy to use. It is a crow that follows you everywhere, by the way. And if you die because you didnt save do not blame me. The crow follows you everywhere. I recommend saving, a lot.

Aya is a little girl on the brink of becoming a teenager. Ayais completely and utterly devoted to her father and her bunny, Snowball. Her late mother died to a sickness, which has madeAya dependent on her fathers love. Aya even starts disliking the maid, Maria, for taking her fathers attention. So imagine waking up in the middle of the night to your fathers screaming, youd be pretty wtf too. Did I mention its the anniversary of your mothers death as well? Isnt that nice? Because things weren't creepy enough.

[caption id="attachment_451" align="alignnone" width="300"] Alfred Drevis with a chainsaw - Mad Father[/caption]

Next up in our list is Alfred Drevis, Ayas father. He is a scientist, completely dedicated to his work. He loves Aya very much, but rarely has time to spend with her anymore, as he works a lot. Aya has been onto what he does in the basement for quite some time, but does that stop him? Nope.

[caption id="attachment_453" align="alignnone" width="300"] Maria, Alfred's Assistant - Mad Father[/caption]

Next, comes the maid, and Alfreds assistant, Maria. After his late wife, Monika Drevis death, he then began a more open romantic relationship with her.

Overview of Mad Father

Overall, the game itself is quite straight forward. It also has a lot of characters for you to figure out and feel bad for. Ill leave you guys to figure the rest of the characters out for yourselves. A definite recommend for a heart attack and smash that button or youll die moment.

[caption id="attachment_454" align="alignnone" width="300"] Mash Button mechanics - Mad Father[/caption]

So yeah, you should definitely save that shit.

[caption id="attachment_455" align="alignnone" width="300"] Home Screen - Mad Father[/caption]

You can buy Mad Father on steam: here
