item.title: Game Review - Bendy and the Ink Machine
item.dc:creator: gann.danielle123
item.content:encoded:
I wanted to take a step out of my usual comfort of RPGs. Regrets. This game is still an indie horror and is still a kind of demo. Think of it like The Walking Dead game, each progression has chapters. Bendy and the Ink Machine is also quite literally a Disney horror-esque game. Good luck. Major Spoilers Ahead, youve been warned.

Protagonist

We start off the game as Henry, not that we changecharacters or anything, youll probably want to though. Henry used to be an animator, and after thirty years away from his job place, Henry returns after receiving an interesting letter from an old friend and boss, Joey Drew. Joey wants Henry(Us) to go back to Joey Drew Studios so that he can show him something amazing. I like the characters, but sincewe dont really know much about them, what they look like, or even why Henry dropped out of being an animator thirty years ago, it makes it hard to sympathize with him. Because really, thirty years later and you still have attachment issues?

Antagonists

We obviously know who the first and foremost antagonist is, Bendy the Dancing Devil. Youd think they would have known something would be up if you animated something with the word devil in it. Anyway, as shown in chapter 1 of the series, we see a giant blob monster of a melting Bendy who seems insistent on our demise. I suppose we deserve it because we saw a rib-cage ripped open Boris in another room, who happened to be Bendys best friend. Thanks, Joey. Since were only human, we run to the exit and get trapped in the basement as the floorboards collapse. Supposedly in Chapter 3, there will also be Alice Angel, another animated character, but we dont know if shes friend or foe, yet. Or even if she shows in the game at all.

Gameplay Overall

Our one and only objective in the first chapter is to turn on the Ink Machine. You go around looking for items to sacrifice to the Ink God or something. Joeys idea, or maybe Sammys. Though as soon as you get the ink flowing, there goes Bendy, old rascal. Popping out of the Ink Room to kill you. Now get the hell out of there before Bendy eats you alive. I almost thought maybe, just maybe wed make it. Nope. As you run to the exit the floor breaks under you and you fall to the basement floor(As said before). Miraculously alive too. How much suffering that drop could have saved you from. The game is pretty straightforward, however, kill those Searchers(Ink-based blob monsters that spite you), press that button, break that board, etc. All Henry knows is that its not safe and he has to leave(Smart cookie). The game is a great scare and an even greater trip to the past. Be safe everyone. Dont do what Henry did.

item.title: Xbox One X - The PC Killer? [LOL Nope]
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded:
Over the past few months, there has been a great deal of hype around the Xbox Scorpio. Finally, at E3,there is much more information about the newly named Xbox One X. [caption id="attachment_467" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The Xbox One X[/caption]
Why is an article about a console on PCMRHub?
Manypundits claim that the XB1X will be aPC killer, running games at 4K 60FPS for$500 USD. Before we move on, there isno waythe Xbox One X will be able to play all titles at 4K 60FPS with high graphical fidelity. Compromises will have to be made. Based on GPU specs, the Xbox One X lookssignificantlymore powerful than other consoles. Forza Motorsport 7 is the only game that is confirmed to run at 4K60FPS. It will probably run at the PC equivalent of medium settings. The XB1 X will also be held back because it is not a new console. This is the third refresh in the Xbox One lineup. Microsoft will not be able to significantly increase their console power without ditching the old XB1 series.
  • 900p/1080p XB games should run at native 4K
  • Xbox One/360 games should have a performance boost
  • Includes liquid cooling
This console will not outperform PCs for $500USD, and it will not run games at 4K60FPS. Video: [embed]https://youtu.be/6wvmA-hggAw[/embed]

item.title: AMD reveals its NEW Ryzen PRO processors. (RIP Intel)
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.content:encoded:
One thing we fail to realise as PC Gamers is that despite our exponential growth and presence in numbers over the past few years, we still only represent a small minority of the consumer market for computers and their components. You might think that by buying a new 200 processor is a fairly expensive ordeal and that you are netting that respective CPU's manufacturer a fair bit of profit for that product, but the reality of the situation is that single processors purchases really do not amount to that much when you consider that every few years thousands of enterprises purchase thousands of ready to go systems in 2-4 year upgrade cycles. In fact, this is where the majority of all income comes in for chipmakers like Intel through their vPro line of chips.(Chips that have had known security flaws leading back to 2008!) However, AMD is looking to change this with its recently detailed "RYZEN PRO" processors, a complete enterprise overhaul of its existing Ryzen chips that are arguably disruptive enough to the CPU market. [caption id="attachment_477" align="alignnone" width="548"] The announced RYZEN PRO variants of AMD RYZEN processors.[/caption] The CPUs are near identical to the non "PRO" variants and therefore serve no real purpose to the average consumer like you and me, however, for a business or enterprise environment they offer a lot of useful features such as:
  • Memory encryption to prevent low-level data snooping.
  • Full support for TPM (Trust Platform Module Interfaces).
  • Full support for secure boot.
  • 3-year warranties (Triple that of the consumer grade versions).
  • 2 year guaranteed manufacturing and parts.
  • AES 128 Bit Encryption.
  • Windows 10 Enterprise security support.
  • Dash manageability for IT deployment experts.
These features may not sound that interesting to gamers or laymen alike however it should shake up the business grade desktop sector considerably when you consider that many businesses are cheapskates when it comes to IT systems and when you consider that AMD Ryzen chips are offering 8 cores and 16 threads of performance on a nonHEDT line of systems for a fraction of the cost of a 4 core Intel machine, it really begs the question, how many enterprises will actually be using Intel chips in their next quadruple digit order of computers? This could be the final step for AMD to monopolise the market and take it back after years of absence from the scene. Yes they have been relatively inactive before the release of Ryzen however AMD clearly still have the contacts and resources to build out a large customer base when you consider the fact that many OEMS like Dell have already stated they will be primarily using AMD chips in their products such as the generation 14 PowerEdge servers and their Alienware Area 51 desktop. If AMD can do this then they will surely have no problem scoping out the same level of customers for these enterprise systems in the workplace (Maybe by cost alone or the warranty that covers the chip for most of its lifecycle) and in doing so they would be taking one of Intel's largest streams of revenue from beneath their feet and then channeling it to themselves instead. Hmmm. I can only speak for myself here, but with the massive success of AMD Ryzen, I personally have no problem with AMD having extra money for R&D purposes. With what AMD has done with so little, I can't wait to see the second iteration of innovation that AMD could bring with Ryzen 2 through funding and R&D, and then I cant wait for the innovation that Intel could bring in retaliation. Competition really does drive innovation.

item.title: Take-Two Pulls Out - OpenIV Modding Returns!
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded:
Take Two Interactive shut down OpenIV, a popular modding tool for GTA games. In an official statement, Rockstar games and T2 stated that OpenIV was a threat to their online community, but the modding tool is widely used strictly for offline enhancements. [caption id="attachment_484" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The Hulk Mod.[/caption] After major backlash through social media and user reviews, T2 realised their mistake. They removed their"cease and desist" claim against the OpenIV team. Rockstar games already faced major repercussions for trying to shut down mods, as shown by their tanking Steam reviews. [caption id="attachment_483" align="aligncenter" width="246"] Steam reviews after the removal of OpenIV.[/caption]

Why Remove OpenIV Mods?

There are many obvious, underlying reasons for T2 to remove mods from the users.
  • Selling paid mods [Following Bethesda's footsteps]
  • Bringing more people into GTA Online [More profit through micro-transactions]
  • Lack of Online security

Rockstar games made hundreds of millions of dollars through Online microtransactions, so it would be beneficial to them to get as many people away from Single Player as possible. Removing single player mods removes the backbone of the game itself.

Paid modding could be another goal for the company, which requires the removal of OpenIV.

PC Gaming Triumphs Again!

Many modders and content creators rely on modding as a source of income, and T2 was wrong to take that away. OpenIV is yet another testament to the freedom of PC gaming. With enough people, we can change any part of the platform. Other examples of PC gaming winning over large companies include:
  • Shutting down Steam's paid modding service
  • Lack of online subscription fees
  • Shutting down Games for Windows Live

Take-Two Interactive as a Company

By shutting down OpenIV, T2 effectively destroyed their own reputation. Even with the apology, PC gamers should not forget their anti-consumer practices. They tried to milk even more money out of the players, and they should pay for the consequences. I will not be removing my negative Steam review on Grand Theft Auto V. GTA V's Steam Page: http://store.steampowered.com/app/271590/Grand_Theft_Auto_V/

item.title: AMD Ryzen - The Aftermath.
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.content:encoded:
The Aftermath of innovation!

The past year has been a dramatic one for Advanced Micro Devices. A company that for years was an underdog to the chipmaker Intel. The company who held the mass majority of the market share for consumer, prosumer and enterprise grade CPUs for years. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1774"] AMD finally upping their game to Intel.[/caption] But now since the shocking disruption to the market that the aggressively priced AMD Ryzen chips bought. AMD has reaped the benefits with what is being labelled "The biggest market share gain for x86 CPU manufacturers EVER!". This comes after the popular benchmarking company "PassMark" revealed some shocking results. They reported that AMD's share of the market had risen to 26.2% from only 17.8% at the start of the year. This is a 10.4% increase in a QUARTER, an almost unheard of financial gain in most industries in such a short timeframe. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="749"] Impressive figures in an impressive timeframe![/caption] These figures become infinitely more impressive when you consider these facts:
  • It does not take into account any market share gain from "Next-Generation" consoles using AMD chips.
  • The benchmark data was only collected on Windows systems. The real value should be higher with the increasing amount of prosumer users using Linux on their builds.
  • It is only based on benchmark submissions NOT systems sold. Many businesses will import thousands of system but for obvious reasons will not benchmark all of them.
  • It only includes x86 processors types.
This really does show incredible gains in a single annual quarter, when we look at the AMD's official roadmap for its CPUs. It shows us that this may only be the beginning of what could be a revolution in the competition for CPU market share between manufacturers. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="625"] This is only the beginning. AMD is taking aim at Intel's main profit streams and the results could be INTERESTING![/caption]

Will it grow further?

It is almost certain that these already impressive figures will continue to grow. AMD has not even released its Ryzen 3, Ryzen Pro, Ryzen APU and Ryzen EYPC chips to the majority yet. If these processors are as disruptive to the market as AMD's recent processors have been, we could genuinely be looking in a few years at a market where AMD is ahead of Intel for the first time in a long time. Also when we look at AMD's lineup for business systems, it really does seem like AMD is trying to take a large slice out of the market leader, Intel. The shocking part is that we all now know that the score is 7:3 to Intel currently, but by the end of this year the results could be neck and neck and that could lead to a whole host of innovation and changes in this highly dynamic and fluid market sector. AMD is back.

item.title: South Park: The Stick of Truth - Should You Buy?
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded:
First of all, I am a huge fan of the "South Park" TV series. This game is like a 12-hour special. [caption id="attachment_500" align="aligncenter" width="360"] Screenshot of South Park: The Stick of Truth[/caption]

How is it against the show?

It's got everything you need from watching the show; it's hilarious, the gameplay is fun, and it honestly feels like South Park. No other way to explain it. You can definitely play and greatly enjoy this game without knowing anything about the TV Show, but it's great that items and side quests all relate to episodes of the show in one way or another. Technically, The Stick of Truth is an RPG, but the mechanics are very lightweight compared to many others. The fights, levelling systems, and items are all very simple to understand. There isn't a great deal of customization, but you have a few different types to choose from.

My Biggest Gripes

Of course, no game is perfect, nothing is. Like almost every game that gives you story options, there is almost NO difference depending on the choices you make. Some of the choices have huge build ups and lead to almost no difference in the story. The ending is the same. Unless you consider the troll ending another one. The game is too short for $40CAD. I finished it twice, each playthrough taking under 12 hours. In my opinion, any game that takes less than 20 hours to complete should be $20 or less. That's just me though. I have to say, even though there isn't much quantity, the quality can make it seem worth it to some people. 30FPS is the most you can get out of this game. I don't really care that there are no graphics settings because it's supposed to look like South Park. I just feel like the game was directly ported from console to PC without much work done at all to make it a better experience for the PC.

The Verdict

To sum it up, The Stick of Truth is definitely worth it for South Park fans and general comedy fans alike. If you wholeheartedly believe in quality over quantity, definitely go for it. Obviously, try to get it when it's on sale. I honestly wouldn't be able to justify $40 for such a short game.

item.title: Custom Built PCs - The Superior Option
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded:
This is an opinion piece. Feel free to disagree and hash it out in the comments.

Technology Rules All

In todays world, technology rules over all aspects of life, including jobs, economies, cultures, and much more. The PC market is growing rapidly, as there are well over 1 billion computers in use today, according to Forrester Research. Owning a computer is almost a necessary part of living in the 21st century for work, leisure, and communication. Purchasing a computer can be a difficult task for those who are not technologically aware, and poor decision making can lead to a poorly performing system, a waste of money, or other undesirable effects. Although many people believe that building computers are very difficult, seasoned builders refer to the process as Adult Legos. By examining the cost efficiency, complete freedom to customize all aspects of the system, and gaining valuable technical skills, it is evident that building a computer rather than buying a pre-built system is the superior option.

Cost Efficiency

Building a desktop from scratch is almost always a better option than buying from retailers such as Staples and Best Buy in terms of price-to-performance. First of all, buying hardware separately removes the expensive labour fees put in place by pre-built retailers. In a comparison between the costs of pre-built systems against custom desktops conducted by AvocadoOnPC, he was able to save over $400 on the exact same system by building the PC on his own with individually purchased parts, compared to the same pre-built system sold at Staples. Retailers such as Staples and Best Buy often increase the costs of their systems for labour reasons. In AvocadoOnPCs video, Staples marked up one of their systems by over $400! By purchasing the same parts as a pre-built and building it, the user effectively eliminates the labour costs charged by retailers, because they complete the labour on their own! Building the same pre-built systems can potentially save the user hundreds of dollars. Furthermore, building a custom PC allows the user to remove expensive parts they do not require to save more money. For example, a basic copy of Windows 10 can cost upwards of $100, and almost all retailers account for this and include it in their prices. Many retailers also include expensive software such as Antivirus systems, editing programs, and more, which increase the overall price of the system. This is significant because many users dont require the extra software included, which needlessly drives up the cost for the consumer. If the consumer builds their own computer, they can opt-out of extra software, and even use free operating systems including Linux. Extra software can drive prices up by hundreds of dollars, and when building their own desktop, users have the option to completely avoid these costs. The more cost effective method to avoid labour fees, and the choice to remove unnecessary parts are perks of building a PC.

Customization

Building a computer provides an unmatched level of customization and freedom. First of all, building a PC allows the user to customize their parts to fit their needs. There are over a million different tasks one can complete when operating a computer, with varying levels of intensity. Someone who uses their computer for reading newspaper articles and sending emails requires significantly less power than someone who uses 3D modelling. The range of power required can vary wildly, from reading emails, to mining crypto-currency. Different tasks require different hardware. Programmers may require stronger processors, while gamers may require stronger graphics cards. Having the freedom to choose the specific parts for the job in terms of PCs can only be effectively done by building the system. This can save the user both time and money. Furthermore, the freedom to customize ones PC allows the user to upgrade or modify their system without being forced to purchase first party support or buy a completely new system. Buying an OEM system from retailers take measures to lock the users away from customizability. They may make it difficult to fine tune, change, and upgrade specific hardware due to limiting space, using cheaper power supplies, etc. All electronics are a ticking time bomb, inevitably getting closer and closer to the end of its life. Building a PC can extend the lifespan of a single desktop significantly. The user can choose the fans and power supplies that will last longer. The user can buy newer parts if they need more power, or if their old parts die. This will save the consumer both time and money. Buying a pre-built system will greatly limit customization, and will require the user to waste time and money buying a completely new system, rather than customizing specific parts. The freedom to customize ones PC allows the user to choose parts that fit their needs, and gives them the opportunity to upgrade and modify their system over time without being gouged by first party support systems.

Technical Skills

Building a PC rather than buying a pre-built system gives the user valuable technical skills and knowledge that will greatly benefit them by providing both convenience and experience for job prospects. Custom building a PC teaches the user a great deal of practical knowledge about hardware, software, troubleshooting, and much more, which will provide a great deal of convenience in the future. For example, when a pre-built system is plagued with an issue, the user will not have a sufficient amount of knowledge on the hardware, software, and configuration within their computer, because it was built by someone else. Once an issue arises, the user will have to pay exorbitant fees to the retailer. If they built their own computer, they would have extensive knowledge on their parts, and would be able to understand the basics, and solve many issues with ease, that would otherwise be impossible to solve if purchased from a pre-built retailer. Furthermore, building a PC rather than buying a pre-built system gives the user extremely valuable experience, which can help them with job prospects, and many other opportunities. Every business on earth requires people with strong knowledge based on computers. Computer science degrees usually yield the quickest and best jobs for young people at this time. By building a PC, the user gains skills including PC assembly, basic troubleshooting, software installation, maintenance, and much more. Although building a PC does not provide sufficient skills to work as a computer engineer, it provides a strong stepping stone to entering the electronic job market. The knowledge of PC building can grant many jobs including technicians, sales associates, etc., with some additional training. Having the ability to work with computers effectively through building a PC can provide infinite job and life opportunities. Choosing to build a PC rather than buying a pre-built system as a consumer enables the user to save time and money, and gain relevant experience for future job opportunities. Choosing to build a PC rather than buying a pre-built system is obviously the better option due to the unmatched cost efficiency, freedom of customization, and gaining valuable knowledge on technology. Buying a pre-built system may work right out of the box, but the other advantages gained significantly outweigh the small amount of time required to assemble a PC. The process of building a computer is like putting together an expensive Lego set, and the benefits received down the line will help the consumer in many aspects of their life, both on and away from their computer.

item.title: Ryzen R3 - Final Puzzle Piece Revealed.
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded:
AMD is back in the game. No matter how you feel about AMD or Intel, we finally have competition in the market again, and that's good for everyone. Ryzen R7 and R5 products have helped AMD gain the most market share of any computer tech company in a quarter, ever. And Intel's puzzling X299 platform is unlikely to reverse that trend. While the R7 and R5 products are a vast improvement over their predecessors, they are not traditionally the market segment AMD has serviced over the last several years. With socket AM3+, it was common to start with an FX-6000 or 8000 series processor as a cheap but ultimately non-competitive option to Intel. As those systems inevitably lost ground to contemporary Intel technology, there was nowhere for the AMD owner to go except the ridiculous FX-9000 series, or to jump over to Intel. The sockets that followed AM3+ were also lower-end platforms that didn't threaten Intel's supremacy. Budget and ultra-budget has been AMD's residence for at least half a decade.Even now, many people are reluctant to pay $200 or more for an AMD CPU, want to get into PC gaming as inexpensively as possible or simply don't have the budget for higher-end products. The tide turned with the release of Ryzen. R5 and R7 were a wake-up call to Intel, whether Intel heard it or not is debatable. With R3 AMD is firmly asserting their presence in a familiar space. Add in Threadripper and AMD will have a complete platform ecosystem from budget to high-end, though Threadripper uses an entirely different socket. Budget builders will finally have an alternative to Intel - competitive performance and a coherent upgrade path. In the past five years, AMD has provided great compatibility but poor upgrade potential. Intel has provided good upgrade potential but miserable compatibility. With AMD's promise of at least three years with AM4, we finally have both. Substantial upgrades are affordable for the majority of gamers again. Ryzen R3 will come in two flavours, both unlocked CPUs.Early pricing "leaks" - again, not solid information slate the R3 1200 at $109 and the R3 1300X at $139, very enticing for CPUs that should handle i3 and put pressure on i5.
  • 1300X: 4 cores / 4 threads, 3.5 GHz (stock), 3.7 GHz (boost)
  • 1200: 4 cores / 4 threads, 3.1 GHz (stock), 3.4 GHz (boost)
Ryzen R3 will be the first Zen products not to incorporate SMT, Symmetrical Multi-Threading. As such it won't have the multithreaded advantage over Intel as R5 and R7 do. However, R3 will also not have the relative clock speed disadvantage vs. Intel, especially concerning Core-i3 products. Ryzen R3 will take advantage of Zen efficiency gains coupled with the fact that SMT results in a loss of overall processing efficiency - where Core-i3 CPUs are dual-core chips with SMT, Ryzen R3 will be legitimate quad cores able to process four threads more efficiently. Also, Ryzen R3 models will be unlocked for overclocking - they will probably not be strong overclockers if current Ryzen products are an accurate gauge, but the additional flexibility will allow AMD owners to increase the performance and stretch long-term viability of their systems if desired. [caption id="attachment_513" align="alignnone" width="300"] CPU performance chart.[/caption] If we take AMD's performance graphs seriously (we shouldn't place too much faith in them until they are verified by independent testing), R3 should pretty handily outperform Core-i3 and get fairly close to i5 performance at about half the price. This is consistent with the pricing and positioning of the more expensive Ryzen products. It also means Intel will face more decisions in the budget segment of the market, where Core-i3 has been the reasonable choice for the last four years. Now if GPU prices just float back down to earth, we will have entered a new Golden Age of PC gaming.  

Sources:

http://www.pcworld.com/article/3207630/components-processors/amds-ryzen-3-lineup-brings-competitive-quad-core-cpus-to-the-masses.html https://www.forbes.com/sites/antonyleather/2017/07/14/amd-ryzen-3-pricing-leaked-bargain-100-overclockable-quad-cores-intels-biggest-threat-yet/#1fc1f2991494

item.title: Yes, I am an AMD fanboy...
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.content:encoded:
Why I choose and prefer AMD ...

I have lots of experience with computers. But when I was building my current desktop PC, circa 2012. The most confusing, frustrating and time-consuming job was trying to find a suitable CPU for my workflow. I was bored and embarrassed by my fueling to the throwaway culture of today's society. Upgrading PCs every 2 years for minimal performance increments really bothered me. I decided that my next PC would be, good value AND long-lasting. Thus I chose AMD. This would have been an easy task for the average consumer. When you look at the number of people running Windows XP on ancient desktops today. You could argue that they have had the longevity and value out of their desktop easily. Even if the entire user base was pensioners playing Sudoku on an outdated and unpatched version of IE6! But heck, even a moderate quad-core can last a decade for the average casual gamer. The legendary Intel Core 2 Quad Q6600 still respectably holds it own today against modern chips. [caption id="attachment_528" align="alignnone" width="558"] Pretty incredible for a CPU released a decade ago when pitted against modern models.[/caption] But the problem was and still is that I am not a regular gamer. Yes I dub my computer as a "Gaming PC" as such, but really I spend more time on projects than on gaming. The average user or "gamer" might play a game, watch a film listen or listen to music. However, I found myself engaging in different tasks. I was running multiple virtual machines simultaneously as test beds. I had various SQL Server instances open whilst also programming software in Python to grab data online and to send it to my test SQL database. Sometimes I may have been playing a game like CSGO whilst I was rendering out video projects for school work. The point is, CPU performance mattered to me, as did a budget as you can imagine on a student budget! [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="649"] Running even basic desktop virtualization requires a reasonably powered CPU![/caption] The large problem was that being a student with only 500-600 to spend, performance was a premium I could barely afford. I needed not only clock speeds for rendering and threads for virtualization. I also needed a very specific set of CPU instructions (AMD-V/VT-x, VT-D and AES-NI) to enable abilities for use with virtualization and for secure encryption when using software such as OpenVPN and PFSense. finally This is what I budgeted out for my system as a student:
  • 50 for the motherboard. (Cheap and functional)
  • 50 for a 1TB spinner. (Although when SSDs were cheap I did add a 240GB SSD for 45)
  • 50 for the case and PSU. (Not good enough really)
  • 150 for the GPU (I was still a gamer)
  • 100 for the CPU (definitely a stretch with my requirements)
  • 100 for the RAM (16GB which is alright for virtualization)
Eventually, this is the system I decided on: (After a few GPU, SSD, CASE upgrades ETC) [caption id="attachment_531" align="alignnone" width="1154"] My 5-year-old PC, after a few revisions and upgrades to some parts.[/caption] My alternative plan was to build an Intel I3 system with the other parts remaining the same. I could have gone with an I3 3320 instead with an Intel Chipset motherboard which would have cost the same amount. It would have been decent for gaming, the I3-3220 wipes the FX8350 out with its single core performance. Surely it soon would have choked under any form of heavy synthetic load or virtualization, something an IT student would commonly use. The FX8350's 8 cores certainly gave it the upper hand compared to the I3's hyper threaded dual core structure in my eyes. The AMD FX CPU range suited the bill because as well as having the grunt of extra cores, they also featured full instruction sets all the way down to the base FX4300 quad core. Instructions set always seem to be much more of a premium in Intel's eyes. In layman's terms. The Intel I3 would have been more like a supercar. It's fast, new and efficient. The AMD FX CPU on the other hand is a muscle car, it's slow and inefficient but it has a lot of brute force behind it. Ultimately this is why I chose it, it was alright for gaming (Still is today) and it offered workstation grade performance on a budget that was reasonable for a student. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="613"] Can you use an I3 for anything other than basic gaming, probably but not effectively.[/caption] So as you can gather, the main reason behind my logic was the budget. I understand that being the heavy user that I am, I do not represent the majority of the user base. Therefore I cannot ultimately say that AMD is for everyone. People who want an unparalleled gaming experience generally go for Intel I7 based systems as they are pretty fine tuned towards getting the ultimate gaming experience. For more general systems though, AMD offers incredible performance and features for the money, and this is only set to rise with upcoming price drops to Ryzen and with the expected announcement of the Zen 2 architecture, not to mention the threadripper vs i9 argument. It is a shame that despite AMD's price to performance, they never had a decent market share due to certain bribery and cheating in the highly fluid marketplace. [caption id="attachment_520" align="alignnone" width="667"] 17 of these CPU's are AMD, 4 are Intel.....[/caption]

My personal conclusion:

Ultimately, we are all PC users at the end of the day, discriminating against one another over the choice of hardware is silly and uncalled for behaviour that really gives PC gaming and enthusiasm a bad name overall. Opinions are opinions and sometimes they are best kept to ourselves. Maybe the I3 system could have suited me fine, but personally, I believe that I made the correct decision, the fact that I am writing this article on this system today whilst watching a film while simultaneously running a Fedora based LAMP server virtual machine speaks for itself I believe for workflows like mine.

item.title: Playerunkown's Battlegrounds TOPPLES CS:GO! [PUBG]
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded:
There's a little indie game in early access making its rounds on social media. Playerunkown's Battlegrounds has sold over4 million copies in 3 months. The hype for PUBG has lasted longer than any other early access title, and with the successful launch, it usually sits in third place as the most concurrently played title. However, this early access title, though for a short time, had more players online than one of the most popular PC games of all time, CS:GO.

PUBG Has More Online Players Than CSGO

The most mind boggling part of this is that a game that is so hard to run, so expensive, and in early access has so many players online at one time. Even more players online than CS:GO at one time. Miscreated, Ark, and DayZ are just a few disappointing early access games that started with a great deal of hype. There's still a ton of hype for PUBG, and for good reasons.
  • No microtransactions (yet)
  • Huge maps
  • 100 player servers
  • Realistic gunplay/mechanics
PUBG is definitely plagued with poor performance and bad graphics, but the game improves with each new update. Could this be one of the only games to leave early access? This game seems to be a true labour of love, and Bluehole is working hard to make it fun for everyone. Video:https://youtu.be/pqancW7BNKY

item.title: Windows 10 Creator's Update Not For Everyone, Says Microsoft
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday Microsoft announced that the Windows 10 Creators Update will not roll out to owners of PC hardware that fell outside its manufacturer's support envelope. [caption id="attachment_545" align="alignnone" width="300"] Windows 10 creator's update[/caption] Some notable hardware is the Cloverfield series of Atom processors and the Core i7-990X, a Gulftown CPU that started life in Q1 2011. Other chips that appear to be nearing End Of Interactive Support (EOIS) from Intel include CPUs as recent as Ivy Bridge units. Microsoft didn't abandon older hardware entirely; Windows 10 Anniversary updates will still apply, as will security updates by OS generation, for instance, hardware originally running Windows 8.1 will receive security updates until 2023 (a promise since broken, BTW). But MS seems to be sticking to its position that their latest OS versions will only run on the latest hardware. I'm pleased with Windows 10 gaming performance, although I've noted some system glitches on my older platforms that are running Windows for up to 48 hours after the scheduled monthly update, particularly where graphics are concerned. This announcement affects more than your CPU. Any PC component could fall out of Windows 10's favor due to lack of ongoing support from the manufacturer. Notably absent from the source article (link below) is any mention of AMD hardware. Until very recently, AMD has had no choice but to support it's older platforms. We have yet to see whether AMD will decide to continue doing so.
Conclusion
Will this decision by Microsoft spur sales of newer PC hardware, or just prompt owners of legacy hardware to try hardware-friendly and easy-to-use Linux distributions like Mint and Ubuntu? Gaming support on these operating systems is much improved compared to the Linux distros of yesteryear, but it's still light years behind Windows. If this forces more gamers to use Linux, this may be just the impetus needed to spur Linux developers to increase their emphasis on gaming. We'd love to hear your thoughts and feedback, and if you want to read the original article just follow the link below. http://www.pcworld.com/article/3209705/windows/confirmed-windows-10-will-cut-off-devices-with-older-cpus.html

item.title: Ryzen and Memory - Best Practices for Gaming Performance
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded: This article will provide you with a few simple rules for matching Ryzen and memory for maximum gaming performance. When Ryzen and the accompanying AM4 products launched, there were serious issues with memory performance. High-quality boards wouldn't POST with memory speeds advertised by AMD, and if all the slots were populated they frequently wouldn't POST with anything but DDR4 2133 MHZ modules installed. Due to ongoing BIOS updates, memory performance has steadily improved, a crucial benefit for Ryzen as higher memory speeds help close the gap with competing Intel products, especially as it affects us PC gamers. [caption id="attachment_555" align="alignnone" width="2828"] Bios updates released to fix compatibility issues with Ryzen chips[/caption] As I write this article, Ryzen performance compared to the vaunted i7-7700K has closed to within 3% in most games at 1080p - and less than that in some popular titles, a paltry trade-off many are prepared to make considering the added flexibility and utility of Ryzen's substantial core count/thread advantage, and its lower price compared to Intel. If you spend less on the CPU that frees up money for a better video card and it's possible to exceed an Intel system's performance in mid-range gaming systems - $800-$1200 using some good round numbers. The latest BIOS update that focuses on bolstering memory performance is Agesa 1006. The new update includes a number of low-level tweaks that help Ryzen use memory more efficiently, but testing has revealed some very simple rules of thumb for getting the most game out of your Ryzen system. Memory speed matters - This is not new info for anyone who owns Ryzen or has been following the development of AM4. Having saved some money on the CPU, it's best to spend a little extra on RAM. Choose DDR4 3200MHz kits to max out your Ryzen gaming experience. Memory latency matters - This fact is not yet well-known to many PC gamers, but testing various memory speeds and timings have revealed the best performance is achieved using fast memory with low latency. For DDR4 3200, the magic latency number is CL 14. Again, take some of your CPU savings and look for a low-latency kit. It may be a good strategy to look for DDR4 clocked higher than 3200MHz (it may actually be cheaper since the ultra-fast DDR4 doesn't sell as well as 3200MHz) and down-clock it, using tighter timings that should be achievable with lower clock speed. This can usually be done using an XMP profile that will reduce the clock speed and latency for memory manufactured to run at faster than 3200MHz. Memory design matters - This is the last and least important facet of memory choice, but it's worth mentioning as it does slightly improve system performance, and... those frame rates tho. All memory is not created equal, and one difference is how the memory chips are organized on the PCB. When data is ferried to or from RAM, it's sent to a specific chip or chips on the memory module - these units are called "ranks", and DDR4 comes in two varieties, single rank and dual rank. Single rank memory sends read/write commands to a single memory chip. Dual rank memory splits the data between two adjacent memory chips and improves memory performance through a process called "rank interleaving".BIOS updates incorporating Agesa 1006 give dual-rank modules a slight edge over single-rank RAM. Look for these designations on potential memory if you want to squeeze the very last drop of gaming goodness from your RAM: 2R X 4, 2R X 8. You can also just look at the memory (if it's not covered by a heat spreader) If you see only one row of memory chips, it's single rank. Chips organized in pairs are dual rank. Lastly, you may get a clue from looking at the model number of the RAM. We've included a list of currently available DDR4 memory products that meets all the requirements in this article. For the memory below, remember to choose DDR4 3200MHz and stick to 16 GB (2 X 8 GB) or larger kits to take advantage of the dual-rank performance bump. Corsair - Dominator Platinum, Vengeance LPX series G.Skill - Flare X, Ripjaws V, TridentZ series Team Group - Dark Pro Sources: http://www.guru3d.com/news-story/amd-blogs-on-ryzen-memory-performance.html http://www.guru3d.com/articles-pages/amd-ryzen-7-memory-and-tweaking-analysis-review,1.html Please leave comments and feedback, and thanks for reading.

item.title: Maximum cooling for maximum gaming
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded:
This article came about as a result of many inquiries about PC cooling. It will give you some expert tips and tricks to get your gaming rig running cool for maximum performance. We get a lot of questions about what cooler is best for various applications, but almost as important as what cooler you are using is how your total cooling solution works together with your case to keep your system cool. Gaming cases are designed to vent air through the interior in a specific way. Mini-ITX units aside, most gaming cases are meant to create an area of slightly lower than the ambient air pressure inside. This makes it easier to draw cool air in and push hot air out. See the reference pic below for a clear visual guide to installing fans and liquid coolers. Often, the cooler air outside the case is drawn in the front (and bottom where applicable) over the drives and warm air is pulled out of the top and rear of the case. There are some cases that offer more options than this, but the diagram above covers most of the choices you'll be confronted with when you build your first PC. Let's talk about how to go about choosing and setting up your cooling system for best results. Choosing a Case Most gaming cases offer good airflow, but more options are better so look for a case that has plenty of mounting points for 120mm fans or larger. A flexible gaming case should allow you to mount fans in the following locations:
  • Two front 120mm or larger
  • Two top 120mm or larger
  • One rear 120mm or larger
  • One bottom 120mm (optional but groovy)
Many cases also support an installation of AIO liquid coolers in the top, or occasionally top and in the front on the right side, like this Cooler Master N400. If you're planning on liquid cooling now or in the future, make sure you check that the case supports it - just because a case supports two fans in one place doesn't mean you can easily mount a radiator and installs can turn ugly if you try to modify the case. There are a few cases that are designed specifically for air cooling and already have a full complement of fans installed, like the Antec Nine / Twelve Hundred in ATX mid and full sizes respectively. These sturdy cases have a good look and superb airflow with two front and one 120mm in the back, and a monster 200mm fan in the top, all pre-installed. This provides a simple and effective solution for new builders, but these cases are by definition limited - they were designed to be fully functional as-is, and the only modifications you can really make are aesthetic by installing different colored fans. Most of the time you'll have to set up your own killer cooling solution, and generally speaking, the most effective cases come with the least, or no fans installed, allowing the builder to create something effective and unique from the ground up. Installing Case Fans To properly install case fans, follow the markings on the housing. In the pic below, the horizontal arrow indicates the direction the fan spins and the vertical arrow indicates the direction of air flow. Choosing Fans The fans that come installed in most cases are adequate to the task, but what makes an exceptional case fan? In short, good air flow and quiet operation are what's desirable in a good-quality case fan. Let's take a look at 120mm fans (far and away the most popular size in mid tower cases) to get an idea of what separates the truly exceptional from the rest of the pack. In my opinion, it's not worth looking at 120s that flow less than 60 CFM (cubic feet of air per minute.) And if near silence is gold for you, stick to fans that produce under 19db of sound. You don't have to spend a lot on fans at this level, there are a couple great products available - be quiet! Pure Wings 2 and Cooler Master SickleFlow (if you want color) are notable and $8-10. This level of performance coupled with an effective CPU cooler will keep "budget" to mid-range rigs running cool and quiet like we like it. Going up in CFM starts adding to the cost rapidly. If you're running multiple video cards or doing aggressive overclocking plan on paying about $3-5 more per fan for each 5 CFM of increased airflow up to or above 80 CFM. This level of performance will set you back about $25 per fan. TheSilenX IXP fans are superb, with the most aggressive 120s delivering 90 CFM at 18db. Choosing a CPU Cooler Overclocking is still an inexpensive and desirable way to boost your rig's performance, and it can be done safely and reliably with the right CPU cooler in place. We'll be looking at a couple different strategies for AMD and Intel, due to the disparity in attainable clock speeds and the heat generated as a result. AMD Because the most you'll ever see from current Ryzen CPUs is about 4.1 GHz, and due to their low TDP (Thermal Design Power or Point) we're going to place an emphasis on simple, reliable, effective air cooling. It's not that you can't or shouldn't put an AIO over Ryzen, you just don't have to spend that much to get the job done. And here's a little secret - moderately priced AIOs don't work any better (and are sometimes worse) than quality air coolers. For 65W Ryzen 3 and quad-core Ryzen 5 CPUs, an inexpensive but effective cooler like the venerable Hyper 212 EVO is more than enough. If you like, buy an extra Cooler Master SickleFlow fan and use it to configure the 212 as a push / pull cooler - the extra bracket you need is included with the cooler. For the Ryzen big brothers, the six core R5s and eight-core R7s, choose a better air cooler like Noctua's NH-D14 or be quiet! Dark Rock Pro 3. If you choose Noctua, know that you'll need an accessory mounting system not included with the cooler. [caption id="attachment_566" align="alignnone" width="300"] Noctua cooling fans[/caption] And if you do choose an AIO, it's advisable to do your homework and find a review from a site you trust. Not all AIOs are created equal, and some feature truly noisy fans when under load. Intel Since Intel's CPUs have higher TDP and can attain higher clock speeds, we will focus on quality closed loop liquid coolers. Liquid cooling is more easily accomplished in an ATX full or super tower. Like, you won't have to remove your radiator to upgrade RAM or have a hand like Dead Pool after his little amateur surgery. [caption id="attachment_570" align="alignnone" width="300"] NZXT's flagship cooling solution[/caption] For light overclocking (up to 4GHz), or reigning in one of the six core or larger Intels under non-OC conditions, a 240mm radiator should be sufficient. Consider the Arctic Liquid Freezer 240 as a budget solution. It provides good cooling and remains fairly quiet under all but the most strenuous loads. For heavy OC, up to 4.5GHz or higher strongly consider NZXT's excellent Kraken X61 280mm cooler. Highly effective and very quiet, but pricey. Below you'll find a link to Tom's Hardware round up of the best CPU coolers of 2017. Please post comments and feedback, and enjoy the game. http://www.tomshardware.com/reviews/best-cpu-coolers,4181.html
See Also:

NZXT Kraken X61 AIO Liquid CPU Cooler Review

Noctua NH-D14 AMD & Intel CPU Air Cooler Review

be quiet! Dark Rock Pro 2 LGA 1150 CPU Air Cooler

item.title: Early Access Games - Pitfall of PC Gaming?
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded:
Early access games have been rising in both production and popularity in recent years. Many games have come and gone under the early access shield, such as Miscreated, Ark, DayZ, etc. We've all heard of broken messes, but what exactly is early access?

What is Early Access?

With increasing costs of game development, many content creators opt for releasing an early version of their games to the public for a reduced price. This grants the investor with access to the unfinished version of the game for helping with investments, testing, and bug reporting. Allowing developers to have their games funded while in development seems like a great idea, but everything has its bad parts. The major question about early access games is: Are early games good or bad for the community?

How does Early Access Affect the Community?

Paying for early access games are often seen as a gamble. Many of the games that enter early access are never finished, and some are completely abandoned. Once the developers have enough money, they have no purpose to continue creating their game. All early access pages state that the game may not be completed. [caption id="attachment_578" align="aligncenter" width="618"] Early Access games on steam have this sign to alert the buyer.[/caption]

No Accountability

Without corporate investments, developers don't need to feel accountable for their work. If their game has already been paid for, what are a few bad reviews? Releasing games in "early access" is low risk, due to the lack of corporate or professional investors overseeing the game. An investor would push their developer into creating a strong, finished product. Games are often riddled with poor optimization, broken mechanics, and a plethora of bugswithout this integral part of the development process. [caption id="attachment_577" align="aligncenter" width="275"] Day-Z's mixed and negative reviews.[/caption] Many people believe that early access games are just gimmicks to have games tested without paying professionals, and gamers pay for these games to serve the developers.

The Silver Lining

There is a multitude of early access games that have not, and will not ever be released as a full game. However, a few notable games have come out of early access, such as Dont Starve, Kerbal Space Program, and Insurgency. Don't expect these gems too often though. Although there are quite a few drawbacks to these titles, many people believe that its one of the best parts of PC gaming. It gives the developer the peace of mind that they wont go into deep debt while creating their game, as well as allowing users to support developers they enjoy, and try many interesting concepts before their initial releases. Widely enjoyed early access games include Rust and PUBG. Early access games CAN be beneficial to the consumer and developer in many cases. However, putting money into early access titles is often a gamble, where only the gamer can lose. Crowdfunding has been wildly successful in the past leaving investors very content. Since the world isn't perfect, many feel as though they wasted their money.

Justification

This system isnt perfect by any means. Firstly, it doesnt have to go through Greenlight, which means that any garbage can get on the store. There should be a way to hold developers accountable, and Steam hasnt found a way to do that yet. Overall, early access is another option for PC gamers and developers, and options are almost always better. Gamers should do their research and take all early access games with a grain of salt.

item.title: Top 5 ways to save MONEY when building a Gaming PC!!
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.content:encoded:
My Top 5 tips to building a cheap PC on a budget!

PC Gaming is an expensive hobby period. It is also an accessible hobby because you can build a system to fit any spec or budget. Expensive or cheap. Whilst the majority demographic of PC Gamers go for moderately specced desktops with intentions to upgrade every few years, many gamers opt to build budget machines that offer the best "Performance Per Dollar" to ensure that they are they are solid investments and the best utilisation of money. Below are 5 of my favourite tips that I have used over the years to save money when building the ultimate budget PC!

1: Research!

Evaluate what you will be doing with the computer you intend to build. Will you be: Consuming media, making media, Gaming, 3D Modelling, Virtualising? You must evaluate what you will use the computer for and what hardware will best for your workflow. Someone who is modelling advanced objects in CAD software may benefit from Dual Xeon setup with a Quadro GPU and full bank of RAM. On the other hand someone who is only doing light gaming (Think TF2, CSGO, Minecraft) may only realistically need a low-end Pentium CPU and 4GB of RAM. Being realistic with your requirements can save you a TON of money! [caption id="attachment_611" align="alignnone" width="563"] The definition of unnecessary![/caption] Once you know what you need you can shop around and see what offers the best value. Do you need Intel or AMD CPUs? What FPS/Dollar do you need? What about Passmark Price/Performance? Will you be gaming at HIGH or ULTRA settings, because lots of money can be saved by aiming for high settings instead of the barely upgraded "Ultra" settings as detailed quite accurately in this article. Another thing to consider is what manufactures are releasing soon. You may be better off to wait for newer components as they are better value. In fact this is what happened with the "Wait for Ryzen" epidemic which definitely paid off when you look at the value that AMD Ryzen chips given over comparable Intel chips. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="681"] Overused? Yes! Good Advice? Yes![/caption] Even if you cannot afford these brand new components, they will almost definitely bring a price drop to existing components. This might make existing technologies actually affordable for many people. Awesome.

2: Shop around!

We all have out favourite online stores, mine being Amazon. However when you compare prices with other online stores you can often saves $5 to $20 per component. Use sites like PCPartPicker to compare prices between online retailers. You can also see trends in price for components and therefore can judge if they are rising and falling in price. You could better off waiting for further price drops or buying before mining crazes. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="669"] A great tool for aspiring PC Gamers and System Builders![/caption] Our UK readers should check sites that are less known about such as:
  • https://www.scan.co.uk/
  • http://www.ebuyer.com/
  • https://www.cclonline.com/
Our US readers on the other side of the pond however should regularly check sites such as Microcenter and NCIX as they often have crazy deals. Sometimes going to physical stores can net you a fantastic deal when items in warehouses go on sale. I picked up a free Corsair CX PSU at Maplin with my purchase, however this is not an incredible deal with the premium that Maplin charges for PC components anyway. But regardless, a free PSU is a FREE PSU! If you can find coupons online then USE THEM. Even 5% off can save a lot of money on bulk hardware purchases. It is worth summing up which shop it is cheaper to buy each component from. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="3000"] If you are buying the games anyway. A GPU with Radeon Gold Reward may be a good deal![/caption] Also take into account that some hardware, especially GPUs may often include a free game. If you were looking to buy this game anyway then you may save a TON of money by getting that bundle as games can often cost upwards of $60 these days! Shop Smartly, not Lazily.

3: Recycle parts!

Ok, that old beige pc tower sitting in the corner might not look that appealing or even recognisable to anyone born in the 21st century. However it can be a lifesaver for budget pc enthusiasts. Many of your existing computers will include a reasonably branded FSP or Delta PSU (Hopefully a standard ATX one). As long as it has the wattage you need and ATX standard, you should be golden. It might not be efficient or silent, but it sure saves shelling out more money for something you already have, it could save you around 50$! The chassis itself will also hold some use. If you are lucky and it is a standard ATX case, then you can just drop in a new motherboard to save splurging money on a more modern chassis. If it does not have regular ATX screw holes then it is relatively easy to drill your own and install standoffs. This also serves a second purpose by making your computer look like a "Sleeper PC"!. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1600"] Gaming PC in a RETRO case? HELL YES![/caption] Also there are many cheap small items that you can take from your preexisting systems. Although they are cheap, when buying them for a new systems the price soon adds up so you are better of recycling what you have. Hard Drives are a good example because all systems have them and any PC made in the last 10 years or so will use SATA Drives which are compatible with systems today. Optical drives are rarely used today however they are still useful components when installing legacy software or ripping CDs to MP3s. If you have it, you may as well use it! Finally RAM can sometimes be salvaged, many systems over the past few years have DDR3 RAM which is still compatible with many systems today. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="1024"] Have items like these kicking around? Save them from landfill and REPURPOSE them for your next PC![/caption] You would honestly be surprised how many relevant computer components you already own! Don't contribute to throwaway culture, repurpose them for something EPIC.

4: Evaluate software choices!

Do you actually NEED Windows? A PC for media consumption, basic web browsing and simple office tasks would be perfectly fine with a lightweight Linux Distro like LUbuntu or Linux Mint coupled with Libre Office (A Microsoft Office free alternative). A HTPC would suffice with KODI and a small gaming machine would work just fine with SteamOS. By cutting out windows you are saving around $100 which can be put back into hardware. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="638"] Wait what! Why do we even need Windows?![/caption] If you do INSIST on using windows, then you can buy keys cheap on online marketplaces like: Ebay, Kinguin, G2A and "Reddit Softwareswap" however I DO NOT RECOMMEND this approach as they are often stolen keys or OEM keys that are illegal for resale. Microsoft may deactivate your windows at any time, proceed at caution! [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="987"] If its TOO good to be true, it probably isn't![/caption] Again. Research your needs and requirements. 5: Buying Used Parts We all want the latest and greatest parts. I would KILL for a Threadripper 1950X system with a 1080Ti. Maybe even 128GB of RGB RAM (Especially RGB). Possible some NVME drives in RAID0. Hardline WATERCOOLING. But these cost money (Obviously), lots of it. But technology moves on so fast that these parts depreciate in price sooo much sooo quickly. Its like buying a brand new car, only to find that its worth pennies 3 years later. [caption id="attachment_613" align="alignnone" width="816"] OUCH, that is a lot cheaper than the RRP![/caption] In fact. I can never see myself building a PC with all brand new parts EVER AGAIN. When consider that your initial investment will be near worthless in a few years, its better in my opinion to let someone else do the investing for you. You do give up a warranty but hardware failures are so rare nowadays that it shouldnt really keep you awake at night. As long as you do sufficient testing such as MEMTEST86 on RAM, you can be fairly sure that the hardware will last. I only recommend storage as being a brand new purchase for safety reasons. Apart from that, buying used seems like the best way to get performance cheaply during the mining midst of the cryptocurrency craze. By also recycling these parts, you are saving them from being wasted. You are fighting the throwaway culture of today! Not everyone is keen on using used parts for systems. Its not always the most reliable bet. However I know that in a few years from now, if I need to build another PC, the first place I will look for a CPU will be Ebay using the change in my pockets. preferable a Threadripper or Core I9 CPU.

Thank you everyone for reading this article, if you have any other tips for fellow budget PC builders. Please comment them down below!

item.title: No Man's Sky - UPDATED AT LAST[Atlas Rises]
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded:
A Trip Back to No Man's Sky?

It's been over a year since the initial release of No Man's Sky. It was released by Hello Games as a buggy mess, and they were met with a great level of backlash from the gaming community as a whole.

Slow and Steady Improvements

The game is certainly better than it was at release, but their Steam page still reflects how the game was received at launch. It was clear that the game still required a lot of work to meet the bold claims made by Hello Games before launch. [caption id="attachment_617" align="aligncenter" width="300"] No Man's Sky received negative reviews on steam[/caption] Overall, the developers of this game made many promises they could not keep and they lied about features that never made it into the game.

New Update: Atlas Rises

After over a year, the No Man's Sky Atlas Rises update will release, adding 30 hours of new story content, as well as a 'limited' online co-op experience. Update 1.3 will be available for free to all No Man's Sky players, thankfully and rightfully.

The Faults of Online Co-op

The lack of online co-op created a great deal of backlash against Hello Games, due to promises of online experiences at launch. The word 'limited' doesn't make the online experience sound much better either. Here are some of the features you can expect from No Man's Sky's online experience:
  • VOIP allows proximity based voice chat with nearby explorers
  • Portals to travel to populated planets
  • Meet up with friends
The Atlas Rising Update will also make improvements to mapping, and make huge changes to the trading system. The update is expected to bring some visual improvements. The terrain editing tool looks very promising as well.

Should No Man Buy?

When No Man's Sky was released, Hello Games effectively spit into the faces of PC gamers. The game was hyped to extreme levels and released filled with bugs, poor optimization, and lies. After the huge backlash, the developers remained quiet for months on end. It's great to see that the developers realized their faults. They're truly working hard to give gamers the experience they paid for. Although they should've released the game properly from the start, at least they're actively trying to fix their mistakes.

item.title: PUBG Patch Frequency Lowered in Favor of "High Quality"
item.dc:creator: adib
item.content:encoded:
Another Early Access Problem?

The Early Access game taking the PC gaming world by storm decided to lower the volume of patches. Could this be the slippery slope to Bluehole ditching PUBG? Will they join the ranks of unfinished Early Access titles? Out of the plethora of garbage hidden behind the early-access shield, PUBG is one of the few hidden gems. It's been one of the most concurrently played Steam games and took over Twitch for a while. PUBG is a hit and everyone knows it. The developers have done a lot of work on the game, but they've already raked in the cash. Bluehole seems like an honest company who puts everything into their project, but they wouldn't be the first developer to disappear without completing their game. Read more about this in our recent article "Early Access Games - Pitfall of PC Gaming?"where we discuss the issues surrounding early access games on Steam.  

Bluehole's Response

A representative from Bluehole stated that he was naive to announce so many updates early on in development. They stated that they still believed in their target for the end of 2017, but scheduled weekly and monthly updates were unrealistic. These updates will be removed to focus on their high standard of quality, as stated by Brenden Greene. The blog post from the developers is as follows: "Until the official release of the game, we will not have our scheduled weekly or monthly patches rolling out as often as before...having shorter QA test time between pushing updates caused more issues than it solved in regards to maintaining a high standard of quality. We want to put our best content out, and ensure that everything we do is making the game more enjoyable with every update."

The Verdict

PUBG is a great game and is being developed by a great team. Since the initial launch of early access in March, it's a much better game and will continue to get better. It's not easy to create and test updates weekly, so it appears that they just want to fine-tune their creations. Many early access games never leave their unfinished state, but PUBG looks like it's on the right track, even with less frequent updates.
See also: Study Finds Playing Action Video Games May Be Bad For Your Brain

item.title: The Vega Pricing 'Scandal' - Why We Should Zip It
item.dc:creator: ziad
item.content:encoded:
Here's why this unhappy trend is likely going to continue.
With the launch of Vega still the subject of heated debate online, perhaps it's time to take a realistic look at both current market conditions, and the factors, both financial and social that have been at work for several years now as well as the cluster-bump that is online PC gaming info. [caption id="attachment_648" align="alignnone" width="551"] RX Vega Models[/caption] First, cryptocurrency mining is not going away in the foreseeable future. Inevitably this bubble will burst and for gamers, the market will return to relative normalcy. Market supply and demand have always been the primary driver for pricing in every industry and our beloved PC industry is no different. But none of us can accurately predict when that will happen, and until it does we can expect elevated GPU prices, especially for Radeon products. There are several points of frustration here. For me, the primary one is that lower-end Radeon products, specifically Polaris are not great for mining. Yet, as novice miners flood that industry they're snapping up RX 580s half a dozen at a time because, for several years, Radeon cards were the thing to have for mining. What was true three years ago is no longer true, and to date, I have seen ONE YT video that discusses this reality. Vega is turning out to be a mining beast, so is it any surprise AMD and the AIB partners are bilking more profit out of the cards? Their goal is profit, and the mining craze guarantees them additional cash. They'd be fools not to take advantage. AMD has been in a bad financial position for their entire existence. In their glory days, when Athlons and Phenoms stomped all over Intel products, the vast majority still bought Intel. People eschewed the cheaper, faster alternative because people don't buy things based on reason. Buying is an emotional act. Always. Tech companies don't just like money;they need money to develop the next architecture while they support their current products, and it's not a cheap undertaking. With Vega, it's clear AMD made the rational decision to develop a product geared toward the professional market. Vega mining proficiency is a predictable ancillary benefit to the architecture. Professionals and miners both are willing to pay more for the products because, for them, Vega is an investment in generating money. Gaming PCs are not an investment, and additionally, the average gamer isn't willing (or able) to pay what a large company can. The real problem with the PC gaming community is that we think we're more important to tech companies than we actually are. No amount of kicking and screaming about "muh frame rates" is going to trump the fact that AMD can sell the pro version of a card for more than twice what a gaming card brings - even with RX 500 series cards current bloated price tags.. NVidia's profit margin is even higher. And AMD needs that juicy profit margin if they're going to continue to innovate. In fact, some industry experts have predicted that at some point, gamers will be relegated to integrated graphics - products like APUs, as both NVidia and now AMD seem to be moving away from the consumer market and toward the much more lucrative markets for pro use, deep learning and other realms. Finally, the mining craze is like any situation where a large number of people with relatively little knowledge jump into a new endeavor. In fact, people can use ASICs to mine more effectively than GPUs, provided they choose the "right" cryptocurrency.. The gaming community, in aggregate has created the current situation. It's time to get realistic about our situation. Unless we are willing to pay over $600 for an RX 580 equivalent, we have no leverage over AMD. Nor should we express righteous indignation for them doing what NVidia and Intel have been doing for years - capitalizing on the market to make more money. Outrage is not the problem; inconsistent outrage is. Update: Now memory prices are supposedly going up as well. I so thought 2017 was going to represent the start of a new "Golden Age" of PC gaming. Instead it just means we need more gold to play.

Sources:

Various cards tested for mining: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xB_y31bfknw&t=322s Last gasp of PC gaming cards?https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JVPUjadCyh8&t=25s GPUs vs. ASICs:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_p1kkScU1Uk RAM prices rising:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X2G3IXVIKuQ

item.title: Coffee Lake - Why You Shouldnt Upgrade
item.dc:creator: fedginator
item.content:encoded:
Coffee Lake is out! Finally, Intel has done what so many have asked for - increase core counts on mainstream CPUs. So why does it feel so hollow and uninspiring? From my perspective, it is because Kaby Lake to Coffee Lake single core and gaming performance is either identical or worse (though not by much). For the flagship 8700k, in multicore, it still loses to an overclocked r7 chip while costing more and the value crown remains firmly in the 1600s camp. So who is the 8700k for? Lets look at use case and characteristics required for each.

For Gaming - a story of clock speeds.

For gamers, there is no good reason to upgrade from a 7700k for 95%+ of games. In most cases, the 7700k wins by a slim margin. Quite why this is so is not clear, but most likely it is due to the fact that CoffeeLake chips have dynamic boost clocks on the 7700k all cores ran at 4.5 max, whereas on the 8700k if all cores are under some kind of load they will top out at 4.3 a mild difference but enough to explain the difference seen. But overclocking should solve that right? Well Not so much. The term Silicon Lottery is thrown around a lot but in recent years has meant very little. Ryzen has a range of 3.9-4.1GHz that 99% of chips fall into. SkyLake the same with 4.6-4.8GHz being its limit. But that all changed when the fire nation attacked. Starting with Kaby Lake, Intel CPUs started to run hot REALLY hot. So hot, in fact, it brought de-lidding from a niche practice of hardcore overclockers to the mainstream of PC enthusiasts. Kaby Lake overclocking was a little more varied typically 4.9-5.1GHz, but even 5.3 wasnt unheard of by any means, but without de-liddingto deal with the temperatures good luck reaching anything above 5.0. [caption id="attachment_696" align="alignright" width="232"] Comparison of die shots - Kaby Lake-M top, Kaby Lake-S bottom. key point being the increased size due to the extra cores of the desktop processor.[/caption] Coffee Lakeexpanded on this. Being equally hot when running at high clocks (each core is basically the same anyway) but now with 50% more cores to deal with. Even a day or so after launch ranges for overclocks varied wildly, from 4.6GHz at the low end to 5.4GHz at the high. This means the silicon lottery is essentially a thing again. And though some may like the thrill of the lottery to me it speaks of something deeper as Intel must have increased die size by adding 50% more cores the rate of imperfections is increasing and creating greater variance. Such variance could, therefore, be pointing towards Coffee Lake being lower quality silicon than Kaby Lake.

Streaming - Can Intel Coffee Lake steal the Ryzen motherland?

For streamers? The 8700k remains worse than a 1800x/OCed 1700 so why change from that? The isolation and lack of impact on the games primary thread having 16 threads give you is extremely important not only in minimums and frame time consistency but also with regards to stream quality. And though the 8700k provides 6 cores which is a step forward its still behind the red team in this regard. In addition to this, Ryzen typically provides better streaming quality even when cores and threads are accounted for (eg - versus a 6900k). Why it does I don't know (and frankly don't care), but it's true whatever the reason.

Value - Can Intel steal the OTHER Ryzen motherland?

For value buyers? HELL NO! Though an 8700k nearly matches an overclocked r7 chip it is not only more expensive and requires a custom cooler but also requires a much more expensive motherboard due to Z370 limitation and that motherboard may not even last long. Overall that means for similar multicore performance you'll be paying an extra $150ish. And this ignores the fact if you want the value, 1600 is far better anyway. You likely lose 35% performance-wise going with an overclocked 1600 vs an 8700k (going by UserBenchmark at least) but at LESS THAN HALF the total price. As much as anything the fact Intel can add 2 cores and increase prices negligibly yet still be this far behind is more a testament to how outright terrible Intels value was previously. As with the core and thread count mentioned before coffee Lake is a step in the right direction, but they have a long way to go match AMD is this context.

So what went wrong? Return of the Ryzen!

So far this seems very gloomy, but why? Simple answer: AMD beat them to the punch. People who needed affordable multicore CPUs (ignoring the clusterfuck that was bulldozer) will have already jumped to Ryzen. And gamers who want the best in terms of frame rate will have jumped to the 7700k will have no desire to change as for them the 8700k is no better. The entire range seems stuck between a rock and a hard place. There will be a few who get the best of it: hardcore gamers who also stream and anyone who plays a lot of CIV VI, but otherwise, upgrading is hard to justify. It's strange that probably the best all-around CPU on the market today (8700k) has no real niche. But that seems to be the case. Why? Simply, the timing was off. If this was launched 7 months ago (ie. instead of Kaby Lake), Ryzen would have been dead in the water a few people would have found a use for them, but no more than a few. If they had waited until 10nm was ready or otherwise improved single core performance it would have been an upgrade for almost everyone - unless Ryzen2 brings something very special. However, they did neither - they launched it now with a confusing and unfinished platform - evidenced by the other chipsets and CPU launching at least 7 MONTHS later in Q2. Intel rushed it in an attempt to stop people buying Ryzen by essentially paper launching the coffee Lake line - in many countries k CPUs aren't available anywhere. Many big reviewers (eg. PC Centric) didn't even receive k SKUs this time and 8700ks seem to already be in extremely short supply and often sold out. This move has even been widely met with skepticism as because many people will be unable to buy Coffee Lake and theyve made buying Kaby Lake new absurd Intel may not be selling many chips in the Q3 and Q4 periods, which are the peak profit periods for most tech companies. In fact, most tech companies make nothing in the first half of the year. And Intels decision could seriously hurt motherboard manufacturers like MSI and Biostar due to people waiting and not buying 200 series boards in anticipation of newer 300 series ones.

What Intel did right - When and why to get some caffeine

But surely there must be some good in the launch? Well yes actually, there is. The i3 line is still pretty much irrelevant due to high motherboard prices go Ryzen 5 at that price range The i7 line is undercut by the i5 gaming wise and likewise overshadowed by Ryzen for multicore performance especially price equalized. So that leaves the i5 series the typical bastion of the gamer. The i5-8400 is a monster. 8700k like game performance and potentially (early reports suggest it fails above 103MHz on non-k chips) BCLK overclocking on a couple of ASRock motherboards mean some serious grunt if you are intent on pushing frames. The 6 true cores will improve minimums compared to the 4 cores of yestermonth and with formidable per core performance near identical to the of the 8700k likely making it all but the same for $150 less (or $100 less if the rumors the BCLK doesnt work on non-k chips is true). For high refresh rate gamers building systems now its a godsend Coffee Lake i5s have a near perfect mix for what gamers want.  

Conclusion - so now what?

And in there lies where Coffee Lake will succeed new builds. People with current high-end rigs who were hoping to drop a new CPU (and maybe a motherboard) in it will be disappointed. But if you want to build something new the i7 and especially i5 lines are excellent choices for high refresh gamers that simultaneously open new avenues in usage TL/DR: If you are building your new rig then, by all means, go coffee Lake, but those with a decent PC already there simply isn't much reason to upgrade. Buy a better GPU or some lunch instead.
